While Apple resisted data access requests from the FBI in the US, it has reportedly ceded control of customer data to the Chinese government and removed apps from its App Store in China that are critical of the regime. The author argues that corporations and free-world leaders must choose between financial gain and supporting free speech and human rights when dealing with China.

title: Nvidia sets 4-for-1 stock split, shares rise
summary: Nvidia Corp announced a four-for-one stock split to make its shares more affordable for investors, causing its stock to rise by 3%. This move follows similar splits by Apple and Tesla last year, with Nvidia's split requiring stockholder approval in June and effective mid-July.

title: Pega Infinity patches authentication vulnerability
summary: Security researchers discovered a critical password reset vulnerability in Pega Infinity, a popular enterprise software suite. This flaw could allow attackers to bypass authentication and fully compromise a Pega instance. Pega has released patches for both cloud and on-premises deployments, urging users to update their systems to address CVE-2021-27651.

title: Discovery CEO David Zaslav Steps Down From Lionsgate Board
summary: David Zaslav, CEO of Discovery, has stepped down from the Lionsgate board of directors, effective immediately. This move comes the same week Discovery announced its merger with WarnerMedia, increasing the competitive overlap between the companies. Directors often resign from boards when their primary company becomes a direct competitor.

title: Apple Inc. stock falls Tuesday, underperforms market
summary: Apple Inc. (AAPL) stock fell 1.12% on Tuesday, closing at $124.85, amidst a broader market downturn with the NASDAQ Composite and Dow Jones Industrial Average also declining. This marked the stock's second consecutive day of losses, placing it $20.24 below its 52-week high. The article also notes Apple's performance compared to competitors like Microsoft, Alphabet, and IBM, all of which also experienced declines.

title: A Licensor’s FRAND Commitments Do Not Limit A Licensee’s Rights
summary: This article argues that FRAND commitments made by licensors do not impose obligations on potential licensees, contrary to views expressed in a previous series of articles. The author contends that FRAND commitments are unilateral decisions by SEP holders to limit their own rights in exchange for broader licensing opportunities, and that licensees retain the right to challenge the essentiality and validity of declared standard-essential patents (SEPs) without being compelled to accept a license. The article criticizes the idea that FRAND commitments create reciprocal obligations for licensees or shortcut the traditional burdens of proof within the patent system.

title: Stock Index ETFs Accelerate Gains to Close Out Volatile Week
summary: Stocks and index ETFs rallied on Friday, driven by technology shares and economic recovery plays, despite earlier weekly losses stemming from inflation fears. While some analysts see the recent decline as a healthy correction, others remain concerned about inflation's long-term impact on monetary policy and market stability, even as a robust earnings season suggests upside potential.

title: Epic Games vs. Apple Trial, Week Two: Everything You Need to Know - WSJ
summary: The second week of the Epic Games vs. Apple trial focused on expert witness testimony regarding whether smartphones are interchangeable with other video game platforms and the definition of a market in the digital age. Epic Games sued Apple for alleged antitrust violations after its game "Fortnite" was removed from the App Store, while Apple maintains its app marketplace policies are fair and that Epic breached a contract. Apple's stock market value hit a new record in 2020 amid these disputes with app developers.

title: Aeva announces customer deal; shares soar even after results disappoint
summary: Aeva Technologies Inc. announced a deal to develop a sensor for an "undisclosed large company's" self-driving car program, causing its shares to surge 13% despite reporting disappointing financial results. The company's first-quarter revenue fell short of estimates, and its operating loss more than doubled. Aeva, founded by ex-Apple engineers, specializes in lidar technology for autonomous vehicles and recently went public through a reverse merger.

title: JPMorgan Is America’s Largest Company In 2021, But Amazon Is Rising In The Ranks
summary: Despite a pandemic, America's largest companies grew significantly in 2021, with JPMorgan Chase maintaining its position as the largest for the third consecutive year. Meanwhile, Amazon climbed into the top five, reflecting the growing importance of e-commerce, while traditional giants like AT&T and ExxonMobil saw significant drops in rankings. This year's Global 2000 ranking illustrates the resilience and shifts within the U.S. corporate landscape amidst economic volatility.

title: Under the hood of Australia’s largest sustainable ETF
summary: This article examines the BetaShares Global Sustainability Leaders ETF (ASX:ETHI), Australia's largest sustainable fund, highlighting its strong performance and strict exclusion criteria while also noting the inclusion of companies accused of tax evasion. It delves into the fund's methodology, its holdings (dominated by tech and financial services), and its performance compared to other funds, discussing the complexities of defining "sustainable" in investing. The piece also raises concerns about animal testing and tax minimization among some of ETHI's holdings.

title: Cantaloupe expands with crypto, cashless payments partnerships
summary: Cantaloupe, a software and payments company for self-pay equipment, is partnering with Bakkt Holdings to accept cryptocurrencies and loyalty points at its machines, capitalizing on the shift towards cashless payments and digital assets. This move follows another partnership with Castles Technology to enhance cashless operations at unattended retail outlets. The company, which rebranded from USA Technologies, aims to drive revenue growth through these new payment features and planned international expansion.

title: Corning opens new manufacturing facility in Wuhan
summary: Corning Incorporated has opened a new Gen 10.5 liquid crystal display (LCD) glass substrate manufacturing facility in Wuhan, China, co-located with a BOE Technology Group Co., Ltd. plant. This facility aims to strengthen Corning's presence in China and support the production of large-size display panels, specifically for 65- and 75-inch TVs. Despite pandemic challenges, Corning successfully ramped up production at the Wuhan facility, which is its sixth LCD glass plant on the Chinese mainland and second Gen 10.5 facility.

title: Powerley and DTE Energy Launch Industry-First Advanced Rate Management Solution
summary: Powerley and DTE Energy have launched an industry-first advanced rate management solution designed to help energy customers understand and control advanced energy rates, such as time-of-use. This solution combines customer-specific energy pricing with household energy data to provide real-time rate advice and personalized coaching, enabling customers to maximize savings and helping energy companies manage peak demand and drive decarbonization. DTE Energy is implementing this technology in a new Time-of-Use pilot program through its DTE Insight app.

title: Google Pay launches international money transfers with Wise and Western Union
summary: Google Pay has partnered with Wise and Western Union to enable international money transfers for its U.S. users, expanding its financial services offerings. The service initially supports transfers to India and Singapore, with plans to cover 80 countries via Wise and 200 via Western Union by year-end. This move escalates competition in the digital payments sector, leveraging the boom in online payments spurred by the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Harrodsburg glass plant that supplies all iPhones getting $45 million from Apple
summary: Apple is investing an additional $45 million into Corning Inc.'s plant in Harrodsburg, Kentucky, which manufactures glass for iPhones and other Apple devices. This new investment from Apple's Advanced Manufacturing Fund aims to expand Corning's manufacturing capacity and support research and development for new technologies focused on durability and product life. The Harrodsburg plant has historically supplied scratch-resistant glass for all iPhone generations since 2007, along with glass for iPads and Apple Watches, and has previously received $450 million in Apple funding.

title: This Kentucky iPhone glass manufacturer just received a major investment from Apple
summary: Apple is investing an additional $45 million into Corning Inc.'s glass innovation center in Harrodsburg, Kentucky, which manufactures scratch-resistant glass for its iPhones and other products. This investment comes from Apple's Advanced Manufacturing Fund and will be used for research and development to improve durability and product life. The Harrodsburg plant has previously received $450 million from this fund and supports hundreds of jobs.

title: Apple awards Corning $45 million from its Advanced Manufacturing Fund
summary: Apple has awarded Corning $45 million from its Advanced Manufacturing Fund to expand manufacturing capacity in the US and drive research and development into innovative new technologies like Ceramic Shield. This investment builds on $450 million previously provided, supporting over 1,000 jobs across Corning's US operations and fostering continued collaboration on durable glass for Apple products. The partnership has been crucial in developing materials like Ceramic Shield for the iPhone 12 lineup, and Corning is also part of Apple's Clean Energy Program.

title: This KY factory makes the glass for every iPhone. Apple just gave it $45 million.
summary: Apple has awarded $45 million to Corning Incorporated, which manufactures the glass for every iPhone generation in its Harrodsburg, Kentucky factory. This investment aims to expand U.S. manufacturing capacity and fund research and development for new, durable glass technologies like Ceramic Shield used in the iPhone 12. The funding comes from Apple's Advanced Manufacturing Fund and supports over 1,000 jobs in Kentucky, deepening the long-standing collaboration between the two companies.

title: Samsung to jump into laptop processor market with Exynos chip in H2
summary: Samsung Electronics is set to enter the laptop processor market in the second half of this year with a premium Exynos chip, targeting the rapidly growing global laptop market. The new Exynos chip will feature a GPU developed with AMD, focusing on improved computing power and battery efficiency with 5-nanometer processing technology. Samsung's move follows other tech giants like Apple and Qualcomm, who have also developed laptop-grade chipsets, as the company seeks to compete with market leader Intel.

title: Apple Has Hired Cisco's Stella Low As Its Head Of PR
summary: Apple has hired Stella Low, former communications chief at Cisco, as its new vice president of worldwide corporate communications. She will report directly to Apple CEO Tim Cook and fills a role that has been vacant for nearly two years. Low's appointment comes at a critical time for Apple, as the company faces high-profile legal battles, geopolitical tensions, and prepares for significant product launches.

title: Fox Factory Bolsters Management to Lay the Foundation for Next Phase of Growth
summary: Fox Factory Holding Corp. (NASDAQ: FOXF) announced key leadership additions to support its next phase of growth and strategic vision. Tom L. Fletcher has been promoted to President, PVG Business & Corporate Strategy, Toby D. Merchant joins as the first Chief Legal Officer & Secretary, and Jackie B. Martin has been promoted to Chief Purpose & Inclusion Officer. These appointments aim to strengthen the company's capabilities in various critical areas.

title: Self-driving startup Aeva says its sensor can detect vehicles over 500m away
summary: Self-driving sensor startup Aeva Technologies Inc. announced that its lidar sensor can detect other vehicles beyond 500 meters and pedestrians over 350 meters away. This advanced detection range is a crucial metric for autonomous vehicles, enabling them to make timely decisions at high speeds. Aeva, founded by former Apple Inc. engineers, has secured deals with automotive suppliers Denso Corp and ZF Friedrichshafen AG for mass production of its sensors.

title: IBM unveils 2-nanometer chip technology for faster computing
summary: IBM has introduced what it claims is the world's first 2-nanometer chipmaking technology, a significant advancement promising up to 45% faster performance and 75% more power efficiency compared to current 7-nanometer chips. This breakthrough demonstrates that silicon chips still have generational improvements to offer, despite slowing progress in transistor miniaturization. While the technology will take several years to reach the market, it represents a crucial step in computing power and efficiency.

title: Adobe CEO: We’re in the ‘sweet spot’ of the world’s reliance on tech
summary: Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen discusses how the company transitioned from Flash software to a successful Creative Cloud subscription service, benefiting from the global reliance on technology. He highlights Adobe's three businesses being in the "sweet spot" of technological need and his strategies for continued growth, along with addressing the future of women and people of color in the workplace post-pandemic with Catalyst's Lauren Pasquarella Daley.

title: Best Buy savior Hubert Joly details a new approach to leadership
summary: Hubert Joly, former CEO of Best Buy, is highlighted as a business hero for his success in turning around the company by focusing on purpose over profit. His new book, "The Heart of Business," advocates for a "refoundation of business and capitalism around purpose," aligning with growing demands from employees, customers, shareholders, and society, which has been accelerated by recent crises. The article emphasizes that this new model of leadership requires an environment that unleashes "human magic" rather than top-down problem-solving.

title: 3 Clicks to $4,000 a Month in Dividend Income
summary: This article proposes that Closed-End Funds (CEFs) offer a superior alternative to ETFs for generating significant retirement income, highlighting their higher dividend yields. It outlines a portfolio of three specific CEFs—Nuveen NASDAQ 100 Dynamic Overwrite Fund (QQQX), Guggenheim Strategic Opportunities Fund (GOF), and PIMCO Corporate & Income Opportunities Fund (PTY)—that collectively provide an 8.5% payout and strong diversification. The author argues that CEFs enable investors to achieve a substantial passive income stream with a much smaller initial investment compared to traditional S&P 500 dividend ETFs, ultimately leading to financial independence faster.

title: Is the ‘Apple’ juice worth the squeeze?
authors: Nathan C. Goldman and Erynn Stainback
summary: This article analyzes whether the tax benefits offered to Apple Inc. for establishing a new campus in North Carolina are justified by the economic returns. It presents various scenarios demonstrating that North Carolina could recoup its investment within 4 to 29 years through increased tax revenues from new jobs, local investments, other taxes, and corporate taxes. The analysis suggests that even with conservative estimates, the state and local municipalities will significantly benefit from Apple’s presence.

title: Apple’s new M1 chip creates a competitive advantage
summary: Apple has introduced new iMacs and iPad Pros featuring its M1 chip, allowing the company to control its entire technology stack and gain a competitive advantage. This strategy insulates Apple from the global chip shortage affecting other manufacturers reliant on third-party semiconductors. Experts like Richard Barnett highlight that Apple's approach contrasts sharply with the challenges faced by automotive, consumer electronics, and medical device industries.

title: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway rebounds from pandemic with $11.7 billion profit
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway announced a net profit of $11.7 billion in the first quarter of 2021, recovering from a significant loss in early 2020 due to the pandemic. The conglomerate, which owns diverse businesses, saw strong revenue growth as the economy reopened. Despite a massive cash pile of $145.4 billion, Berkshire Hathaway continued significant stock buybacks rather than pursuing large acquisitions, even as its stock performance has lagged the broader market in recent years.

title: I'm Not Turning Off App Tracking On My iPhone, Because I’m A Total Cuck
summary: The author humorously explains her decision to not disable app tracking on her iPhone, despite Apple's new privacy feature allowing users to opt out. She describes herself as a "datacuck" who enjoys personalized ads and wants to see "how far this goes" when it comes to data collection, contrasting her personal choice with the recommended smart privacy practices. The article satirically delves into the perceived benefits of targeted advertising while acknowledging the serious implications of data privacy and Facebook's track record.

title: Apple v. Epic: What to expect from a trial that could change antitrust law and the mobile-app ecosystem
summary: The article previews the upcoming federal court case between Apple Inc. and Epic Games Inc., scheduled to begin on May 3. This high-profile trial is expected to significantly impact antitrust law and the mobile app ecosystem, with the livelihood of app developers and the definition of antitrust law at stake. Epic Games will challenge Apple's App Store rules, arguing they unfairly leverage the tech giant's market dominance.

title: Highwoods Properties Inc (HIW) Q1 2021 Earnings Call Transcript
summary: Highwoods Properties Inc. (HIW) reported Q1 2021 FFO of $0.91 per share and increased its full-year FFO outlook, driven by improved leasing activity and strong performance in its Sunbelt markets. The company also announced plans to acquire a portfolio of office assets from Preferred Apartment Communities for $769 million, funded by selling $500-600 million in non-core assets. Executives highlighted rising office utilization rates, significant job growth announcements in their key markets like Raleigh and Nashville, and continued optimism for long-term growth.

title: These 3 ETFs Sit Atop the Invesco Fund Flows Leaderboard
summary: This article highlights the top three Invesco ETFs by year-to-date fund flows as of April 2021. The ETFs include the Invesco S&P 500 Equal Weight ETF (RSP), the Invesco PureBeta MSCI USA ETF (PBUS), and the Invesco Senior Loan ETF (BKLN). Each ETF offers a distinct strategy, ranging from equal-weighting and pure beta exposure to senior loan investments.

title: Apple sales smash expectations on surging demand for devices
summary: Apple Inc. reported fiscal second-quarter sales of $89.6 billion, significantly exceeding Wall Street expectations, driven by strong demand for the 5G iPhone 12 line, iPads, and Mac computers as people continued working and learning from home. The company's iPad and Mac sales nearly doubled, demonstrating its control over the supply chain and its profitability during the pandemic. Apple also increased its dividend by 7% and expanded its share buyback program by an additional $90 billion.

title: Form 8-K IDEX CORP /DE/ For: Apr 27
summary: IDEX Corporation reported strong first-quarter 2021 financial results, with record orders and sales up 10% overall and 6% organically. The company raised its full-year adjusted EPS guidance to $6.05-$6.20 and announced the acquisition of AirTech Group, Inc. These results reflect improving market conditions and effective capital deployment strategies.

title: LG Display posts strong Q1 profit on panel price boost
summary: LG Display reported a strong Q1 operating profit of 523 billion won, rebounding from a loss in the previous year, driven by increased panel prices due to high demand for TVs and laptops. This exceeded analyst expectations, though a shortage of semiconductors poses a threat to future production. The company noted that IT devices and TVs were significant contributors to its revenue.

title: Looking for an ETF to Hold for the Long-Term?
summary: The article suggests the Schwab U.S. Large-Cap Growth ETF (SCHG) as a long-term investment option, highlighting its strong performance and holdings in major growth companies. It emphasizes the potential for significant long-term returns through consistent investing in such ETFs, despite the allure of instant gratification.

title: What to know about Apple's new privacy update and why it's riling Facebook
summary: Apple has rolled out a new privacy update, iOS 14.5, which requires apps to get user permission before tracking their data. This update has sparked a feud with Facebook, which argues it will disrupt online advertising and harm small businesses that rely on targeted ads. Apple, however, maintains the feature gives users more control over their personal data.

title: Google (GOOGL) stock hits all-time high on Q1 2021 earnings, announces $50 billion buyback
summary: Alphabet (Google's parent company) reported record Q1 2021 earnings, with revenues of $55.31 billion and EPS of $26.29, significantly beating analyst estimates. Google's stock hit an all-time high of over $2400/share in after-hours trading following the announcement. The company also announced a new $50 billion share repurchase program for its Class C capital stock.

title: Apple investing $448 million in Catawba County as part of NC expansion
summary: Apple Inc. announced a $1 billion investment in North Carolina, with a significant portion, $448 million, allocated for expansion in Catawba County. While the new 3,000 jobs will be in Wake County's Research Triangle Park, the Catawba County investment will focus on real property construction and improvements at Apple's existing data center over the next decade.

title: What do Apple’s new privacy settings mean for you?
summary: Apple is rolling out new privacy settings requiring app developers to explicitly ask users for permission to track their browsing habits across other apps and websites. This change is expected to significantly impact the mobile advertising market as many users are anticipated to decline tracking, potentially reducing ad effectiveness and revenue for businesses and publishers. The move has created a rift with companies like Facebook, which argues it will harm small businesses.

title: AirTags review: The Bluetooth tracker only Apple would build
summary: This article reviews Apple's new AirTag Bluetooth tracker, highlighting its seamless integration with the Apple ecosystem, ease of setup, and leveraging of the vast "Find My" network. It contrasts AirTags with competitors like Tile, noting Apple's focus on privacy and superior finding capabilities through Ultra-Wideband connectivity, despite some minor drawbacks like accessory costs and sound loudness. The review concludes that AirTags are a genuinely Apple product, both in design and functionality, designed to enhance the iPhone user experience rather than being a standalone business.

title: Apple incentives are the largest in NC history. Here’s how the deal breaks down.
summary: North Carolina has landed a new Apple Inc. high-tech campus in Research Triangle Park, marking the largest incentive deal in the state's history. The state and local incentives for Apple could total nearly $1 billion over four decades, primarily sourced from new Apple employees' state income tax payments which will be directed back to the company. In return, Apple promises $1 billion in investment across North Carolina and 3,000 new jobs with an average annual salary of $187,000, projecting over $1 billion in annual economic benefits for the state.

title: Apple and Google Are Killing the (Ad) Cookie. Here’s Why
summary: Apple and Google are implementing separate changes that will effectively end the use of third-party advertising cookies, significantly altering how marketers track online activity and target ads. Apple is requiring app developers to gain user permission for tracking across apps and websites, while Google is developing a cookie alternative that allows for targeted advertising without relying on individual web history. Both tech giants cite privacy as the driving force behind these changes, though Google also emphasizes balancing privacy with the financial viability of web publishing.

title: Apple Investing in Hendricks County Distribution Center
summary: Apple Inc. is investing $100 million to build a new distribution center in Hendricks County, Indiana, which will create nearly 500 jobs by the end of 2024. The facility will be operated by XPO Logistics Supply Chain and aims to accelerate delivery times for customers. The Indiana Economic Development Corp. has offered XPO Logistics up to $5 million in conditional tax credits for the project.

title: Artificial Intelligence as the Backbone for the ARKQ ETF
summary: The article discusses how artificial intelligence serves as a fundamental theme for disruptive technologies, specifically highlighting its importance for the ARK Autonomous Technology & Robotics ETF (ARKQ). It emphasizes AI's intersection with other growth themes and its role as a backbone for various products and services, particularly in edge computing. The piece also details how advancements in AI, machine learning, and supercomputing are driving demand for data center solutions and influencing new architectural developments like ARM's v9.

title: Get Growth With Large Cap Stability With The "VONG" ETF
summary: This article highlights the Vanguard Russell 1000 Growth Index Fund ETF Shares (VONG) as a means for investors to achieve growth with large-cap stability. VONG tracks the Russell 1000® Growth Index, focusing on large-capitalization growth stocks in the U.S. The ETF has shown significant growth over the past year, driven by prominent technology companies.

title: The Glazers
summary: This article chronicles the 15-year ownership of Manchester United by the Glazer family, delving into the controversial leveraged buyout in 2005 and its impact on the club. It examines their commercial strategies, financial dealings including debt and dividends, and the persistent fan protests, while also exploring the family's approach to the business of sport, their personal involvement, and the challenges of a potential sale. The piece highlights the significant financial returns the Glazers have received and how their business model transformed Manchester United's commercial operations.

title: Double down on health and fitness with Garmin’s Venu 2 Series GPS smartwatch
summary: Garmin announced the Venu 2 and Venu 2S GPS smartwatches, designed to help users achieve a healthier lifestyle with new features like fitness age, advanced sleep tracking with sleep score, and numerous health monitoring tools. The Venu 2 series offers over 25 built-in sports apps, enhanced battery life, and smart features for daily convenience. Available in two sizes, these smartwatches are priced at $399.99 and aim to provide deeper insights into overall wellness.

title: Get Growth With Large Cap Stability With The "VONG" ETF
summary: The article highlights the Vanguard Russell 1000 Growth Index Fund ETF Shares (VONG) as a way for investors to achieve growth with large-cap stability. VONG tracks the Russell 1000 Growth Index, focusing on large-capitalization growth stocks in the U.S., performing well with a 60% increase in the past year, driven by major tech companies. It caters to investors seeking long-term growth opportunities and capital appreciation over dividends.

title: Here's how much money you'd have if you bought $1,000 worth of Netflix stock in 2011
summary: This article examines the significant return on investment for Netflix stock over the past decade. A $1,000 investment in Netflix in 2011 would have grown to over $15,000 by April 2021, far outpacing the S&P 500, Google, and Apple. Despite recent subscriber growth concerns, analysts believe Netflix is well-positioned for the long term due to its first-mover advantage and extensive content investments, even amidst increasing competition from other streaming services.

title: Signal messaging app reveals flaws in Israeli firm Cellebrite's equipment
summary: Encrypted chat app Signal has alleged that equipment sold by Israeli surveillance provider Cellebrite to law enforcement can be easily sabotaged. Signal's founder, Moxie Marlinspike, claimed to have found security flaws in Cellebrite's software after examining their equipment, making it vulnerable to specially crafted files. These allegations come as Cellebrite prepares to go public through a SPAC merger, valuing the combined company at around $2.4 billion.

title: Encrypted chat app Signal alleges flaws in Cellebrite equipment
summary: Encrypted messaging app Signal has claimed that products sold by Israeli surveillance provider Cellebrite, used by law enforcement, contain security flaws that could be exploited. Signal's creator, Moxie Marlinspike, alleged that Cellebrite's software security is lacking and that he found snippets of Apple Inc. code within Cellebrite's software, potentially posing legal risks. These allegations come as Cellebrite prepares to go public through a merger, valuing the combined company at approximately $2.4 billion.

title: Is Apple a Growth Stock, a Value Stock, or Both?
summary: This article discusses whether Apple (AAPL) is a growth stock, a value stock, or both, examining its classification within Morningstar's Style Box and its historical journey. It highlights how Apple's style assignment impacts investor portfolios and fund performance, especially for index funds and active managers. The authors explain Morningstar's multi-factor style model, which places Apple in the "large core" segment due to its mixed characteristics, and contrast this with other index providers.

title: Apple Launches Powerful New iPad, ‘Air Tags’ to Track Lost Items
summary: Apple announced new products including a powerful iPad Pro with the M1 chip, new iMac computers, and AirTags for tracking lost personal items. The new iPad Pro aims to meet increased demand for work-from-home solutions, while AirTags offer a secure way to locate misplaced objects using the "Find My" network. Apple also unveiled a new podcast subscription service.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Netflix’s Dominance Starts to Slow as Rivals Gain (Published 2021)
summary: Netflix reported a slowdown in subscriber growth for the first quarter of 2021, adding only four million new customers compared to a forecast of six million. This modest growth, coupled with a decline in its share of global demand for original programming, indicates that competitors like Disney+, HBO Max, and Paramount+ are beginning to challenge Netflix's long-standing market dominance. The company anticipates adding even fewer subscribers in the current quarter.

title: Logitech Combo Touch Available for New iPad Pro 12.9” (5th generation) and iPad Pro 11” (3rd generation)
summary: Logitech announced the availability of its Combo Touch for the new iPad Pro 11” (3rd generation) and soon for the iPad Pro 12.9” (5th generation). This versatile case features a detachable keyboard and an integrated, large click-anywhere trackpad, connecting via the Smart Connector. It supports four use modes—typing, viewing, sketching, and reading—and offers protection for the iPad.

title: Chuck Geschke, Father of Desktop Publishing, Dies at 81 (Published 2021)
summary: Chuck Geschke, co-founder of Adobe and a pioneer in desktop publishing, has died at 81. He and John Warnock developed PostScript, a crucial technology that enabled digital documents to be sent to printers, revolutionizing how businesses and individuals could print their own materials. Their innovation at Adobe, including the PDF, significantly influenced the development of personal computing and digital document sharing.

title: Michele Romanow’s Clearbanc hits unicorn status, raising US$100-million at nearly US$2-billion valuation
summary: Michele Romanow's company, Clear Finance Technology Corp., has achieved unicorn status, raising US$100-million in equity at a valuation of close to US$2-billion. The company, rebranding as Clearco, provides cash advances to online sellers and has seen significant growth during the pandemic, benefiting from the surge in online orders. It plans to tap larger sources of off-balance sheet debt financing to fuel future expansion, including a new US$250-million debt facility from Credigy Ltd.

title: AutoX Selects Arbe's 4D Imaging Radar Platform for Level 4 Autonomous Vehicles
summary: Arbe announced that AutoX has selected its 4D Imaging Radar Platform for integration into 400,000 Level 4 autonomous vehicles, including RoboTaxis, over the next five years. This partnership aims to enhance safety and performance by utilizing Arbe's ultra-high resolution radar systems, which offer 100 times more detail than other market radars. The collaboration emphasizes an effort to elevate safety standards for L4 autonomous vehicles, particularly in dense urban environments like those in China.

title: An activist investor calls for a slate of new directors at apparel retailer Genesco
summary: Activist investor Legion Partners is calling for a slate of seven new directors to be appointed to Genesco's eight-person board, aiming to enhance shareholder value through strategies like de-conglomeratizing and cutting overhead. This move marks Legion's second attempt at activism with Genesco, after a previous campaign in 2018 where the investor ultimately sold its position. Despite a strong plan, the author questions Legion's long-term commitment given their past divestment and the absence of a Legion principal on the proposed board slate, suggesting that a smaller board change might be more appropriate.

title: Adobe co-founder, Los Altos resident Charles ‘Chuck’ Geschke dies
summary: Charles M. “Chuck” Geschke, co-founder of Adobe Systems and Los Altos resident, has died at age 81. Geschke co-founded Adobe with John Warnock in 1982, creating PostScript which revolutionized desktop publishing, and the company later expanded significantly into various software areas. He was also notable for his kidnapping in 1992 and his extensive philanthropic work and awards recognizing his contributions to technology and education.

title: Google, Adobe and Samsung top best company culture list for 2021
summary: Google, Adobe, and Samsung have topped Comparably's 2021 Best Global Company Culture list. Google led with an 85% employee approval rating, while Adobe followed closely with 96%, and Samsung was the only Asian company in the top 50. The rankings were based on anonymous employee feedback across 20 workplace culture categories, factoring in companies' handling of the pandemic and employee well-being.

title: For Two Vanguard ETFs, the Growth vs. Value Battle Roars On
summary: The article highlights the ongoing "growth vs. value" debate by comparing two Vanguard ETFs: VUG (Growth) and VTV (Value). While VTV has shown stronger short-term performance with a significant year-to-date gain, VUG has historically outperformed VTV over longer periods, driven by its heavy tech holdings. The piece discusses the investment approaches and expense ratios of both funds.

title: Manager Question of the Month: How Active Fund Managers Cope With Index Concentration
summary: This article discusses the challenges active fund managers face due to increasing index concentration, particularly in U.S. large-cap growth benchmarks dominated by a few technology companies. It explores how managers adapt their strategies, including considering a switch from diversified to nondiversified funds, and the trade-offs involved in maintaining performance against highly concentrated indexes while adhering to SEC diversification rules. The piece highlights various approaches taken by investment firms like T. Rowe Price and Wellington Management.

title: Eli Lilly, riding pharma's rising digital wave, drafts Apple exec to replace Shah as CDO
summary: Eli Lilly has appointed Diogo Rau, a former Apple executive, as its new chief digital and information officer, replacing the retiring Aarti Shah. This move reflects a growing trend in the pharmaceutical industry to recruit consumer-sector digital leaders, particularly as the pandemic has accelerated digital adoption. The article highlights similar hires by other major pharma companies like Sanofi, GlaxoSmithKline, and Novartis, while also noting some instances where such executives have returned to the consumer digital space.

title: Eli Lilly and Company hires Apple's retail information technology chief
summary: Eli Lilly and Company has hired Diogo Rau, Apple's former chief of information technology for online and in-store retail, as its new senior vice president and chief information and digital officer. Rau will lead Lilly's initiatives in data use, analytics, and machine learning, succeeding Aarti Shah. His previous experience at Apple included developing technologies for the Apple Online Store and retail stores.

title: Paycom boss Chad Richison's net worth: Inside highest paid CEO's $211M package and philanthropy work
summary: Chad Richison, Paycom's founder and CEO, became the highest-paid CEO in the S&P 500 in 2020 with a compensation package worth over $200 million. This package includes 1.61 million restricted shares tied to aggressive performance goals, potentially adding billions to his net worth if Paycom's share price significantly increases. Richison, with a net worth of around $2.9 billion, is also known for his philanthropic efforts, having signed the Giving Pledge and founded the Green Shoe Foundation.

title: Israeli digital forensics startup Cellebrite to go public via SPAC in $2.4B deal
summary: Cellebrite, an Israeli digital forensics startup known for phone hacking, is set to go public through a SPAC merger with TWC Tech Holdings II Corp. The deal values the company at approximately $2.4 billion and will provide $580 million in cash, including a $300 million private investment. The combined company will be listed on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "CLBT."

title: JPMorgan’s Chief Sees a Boom Coming (Published 2021)
authors: Andrew Ross Sorkin Jason Karaian Sarah Kessler Michael J. de la Merced Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon predicts a potential economic boom extending into 2023 driven by excess savings, deficit spending, infrastructure plans, and vaccine-induced euphoria, though he warns of potential inflation and aggressive interest rate hikes. He also addresses concerns about the growing influence of shadow banking and big tech in finance, China's perception of American decline, and the complexities of addressing climate change. Dimon's annual letter also touched on remote work reducing office space needs, cybersecurity spending, and specific tax loopholes he believes should be closed.

title: Targeting Overseas Tax Shelters (Published 2021)
summary: This article discusses how Bristol Myers Squibb used offshore tax shelters in Ireland and other locations to avoid paying an estimated $1.4 billion in U.S. federal income taxes. The Biden administration plans to crack down on these practices by proposing a global minimum corporate tax rate of 21% to fund infrastructure projects. The article explores the history of such tax avoidance schemes, the motivations behind them, and the challenges the Biden administration faces in implementing its new tax policies.

title: Meet the highest paid CEO in S&P 500, Paycom’s $211M man
summary: Chad Richison, the founder and CEO of Paycom Software Inc., was awarded compensation valued at $211 million in 2020, making him the highest-paid CEO in the S&P 500 based on disclosures so far. This compensation package, centered on restricted shares, could be worth over $2 billion if Paycom's stock price significantly increases, demonstrating a performance-based alignment with shareholder interests. Richison's equity award is contingent on the company's share price more than doubling and reaching specific targets within the next decade.

title: Asian-American business leaders rally against wave of hatred: ‘We don’t deserve to live in fear in our own country’
summary: Asian-American business leaders are speaking out against increased violence and animosity towards their communities during the COVID-19 pandemic. Many Asian Americans, who form a significant portion of Silicon Valley's tech industry, are using their platforms to voice their concerns. The article highlights an incident where Debby Soo, CEO of OpenTable, experienced discrimination in a grocery store, illustrating the pervasive nature of this prejudice.

title: Judge dismisses Koss Corp. patent suit against Skullcandy. Cases vs. Apple, Bose continue.
summary: A judge has dismissed Koss Corp.'s patent-infringement lawsuit against Skullcandy Inc. due to a geographic-venue issue. However, Koss Corp. is continuing its patent cases against four other companies, including Apple Inc. This development comes as Koss Corp. seeks to protect its intellectual property in the headphones market.

title: Gartner Forecasts Global Devices Installed Base to Reach 6.2 Billion Units in 2021
summary: Gartner forecasts the global installed base of devices (PCs, tablets, and mobile phones) will reach 6.2 billion units in 2021, driven by permanent changes in device usage patterns due to the pandemic, including remote and hybrid work. The number of laptops and tablets is expected to increase significantly, while smartphone market confidence returns with a projected 1% increase in installed base in 2021. The article highlights the increasing complexity for IT services due to a mix of company-owned and personal devices and a rising demand for connected 4G/5G devices.

title: Deluxe Acquires Sony Electronics’ New Media Solutions Division
summary: Deluxe has acquired Sony New Media Solutions, a division of Sony Electronics, to enhance its digital media supply chain capabilities for studios and streaming services. The acquisition is expected to strengthen Deluxe's technology and workflows, providing NMS customers with full access to Deluxe's integrated supply chain solutions, including localization and distribution. This deal follows Deluxe's earlier acquisition of Sundog Media Toolkit, further expanding its cloud automation resources.

title: MicroVision (MVIS) Stock Forecast: Will Microsoft Buy the Company?
summary: MicroVision (MVIS) stock surged over 50 percent on March 31, 2021, driven by rumors of potential acquisition interest from tech giants like Apple and Microsoft, especially after Microsoft secured a $22 billion contract with the U.S. Army for augmented reality headsets, in which MicroVision is believed to be a supplier. Despite this growth, MVIS remains a speculative investment due to its low revenue, lack of analyst coverage, and high volatility, with its CEO acknowledging the company is "up for sale."

title: Sony undergoes 1st name change in 6 decades to Sony Group
summary: Sony Corp. has rebranded itself as Sony Group Corp., marking its first name change in over six decades. This change reflects the company's shift towards functioning as a conglomerate, focusing on diverse areas like financial services, gaming, and entertainment, rather than solely electronics. The move aims to maximize synergies among its various group companies and foster growth in new sectors.

title: moomoo – 1 Free Apple share and commission-free trading
summary: The article introduces Futu Singapore's moomoo trading platform, highlighting its features like in-app announcement alerts, detailed shareholder information, and access to multiple markets with low fees. It also details a promotional offer for new users, including a free Apple share and commission-free trading, alongside emphasizing the benefits of discount brokers for Singaporean investors.

title: Arm’s v9 Architecture Explains Why Nvidia Needs To Buy It
summary: This article explores why Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings, initially questioned, makes strategic sense following Arm's v9 architecture announcement. The v9 architecture's focus on integrating vector math, matrix math, and digital signal processing into CPUs, alongside new security features and a "Realms" memory partitioning system, suggests a future where specialized, highly integrated compute on-device is paramount. Nvidia's move to acquire Arm is positioned as a bet on this evolving compute landscape, where a single, malleable architecture can support a vast array of devices from IoT to datacenters, potentially limiting the expansion of hybrid CPU-GPU models for certain workloads.

title: The China challenge: Why Intel is too strategic to fail
summary: This article analyzes Intel's strategic shift to IDM 2.0 under CEO Pat Gelsinger, focusing on the company's plan to leverage internal manufacturing, external foundries, and a new Intel Foundry Services division. It examines the market changes impacting Intel, the critical threat from China's semiconductor ambitions, and the need for significant partnerships, including with IBM and the U.S. government, for Intel to regain its leadership and combat the China challenge. The authors argue that despite positive steps, Intel needs even more substantial changes, possibly a joint venture with a volume leader like Samsung, to succeed.

title: Invesco unveils Nasdaq ‘next generation’ ETF
summary: Invesco has launched two new ETFs, the Invesco NASDAQ Next Generation 100 UCITS ETF (EQJS) and the Invesco Nasdaq-100 Swap UCITS ETF (EQQS), expanding its tech ETF range. EQJS tracks the Nasdaq Next Generation 100 index, mirroring a US-listed strategy, while EQQS provides synthetic exposure to the Nasdaq 100, designed to mitigate withholding tax on US equity dividends. These new offerings are listed on the LSE with competitive total expense ratios.

title: Newfound Popularity of Thematic ETFs
summary: Thematic ETFs, which invest in baskets of stocks benefiting from emerging trends, technology, or evolving economic landscapes, have seen a significant surge in popularity since October 2020, with AUM growing by 132%. Despite this growth, the article highlights potential risks associated with these ETFs, including the reversal of investor enthusiasm impacting fund flow and performance, the concentrated holdings of individual stocks within the ETFs, and the potential for misleading diversification that may dilute thematic exposure and justify higher fees. Investors are advised against chasing "hot" ETFs without understanding their underlying holdings and potential risks.

title: In $20bn push, Intel hopes to make US chip-making great again
summary: Intel announced a significant expansion of its advanced chip manufacturing capacity with a $20bn investment to build two factories in Arizona, aiming to regain its market leadership and challenge rivals TSMC and Samsung. CEO Pat Gelsinger's strategy includes opening Intel's plants to outside customers in a "foundry" business model and focusing on cutting-edge computing chip manufacturing. This move is also a response to US and European concerns about the concentration of chipmaking in Asia and seeks to boost domestic production.

title: Intel to spend $20 billion on U.S. chip plants as CEO challenges Asia dominance
summary: Intel announced plans to invest $20 billion in two new chip manufacturing plants in Arizona, aiming to expand its advanced chip production and open its factories to outside customers. This move by CEO Pat Gelsinger directly challenges the dominance of TSMC and Samsung in the advanced chip market and seeks to shift the technological balance of power back to the U.S. and Europe. The company expects $72 billion in revenue and adjusted earnings per share of $4.55 for 2021, and the new strategy is intended to restore Intel's reputation and create 3,000 permanent jobs.

title: Clarivate celebrates BD’s culture of innovation
summary: Clarivate has named BD to its Top 100 Global Innovators 2021 list for the sixth time, recognizing the company's significant investment in innovation and its commitment to protecting intellectual property. BD invests over a billion dollars annually in innovation, contributing to advancements in medical technology, and holds approximately 27,000 active, issued patents worldwide. The recognition highlights BD's ongoing efforts to advance global health through pioneering solutions and a robust intellectual property portfolio.

title: “Think twice about whose money you take”: 21 tips for aspiring unicorns
summary: Lior Handelsman, co-founder of SolarEdge and now with Grove Ventures, shares 21 essential tips for aspiring entrepreneurs, drawn from his experiences building SolarEdge into a billion-dollar company and investing in startups. His advice covers critical aspects like aiming big, securing funding, managing valuations, team dynamics, and the psychological demands of entrepreneurship.

title: Laptop Bench Test: Dell Latitude 5410 – An upgrade in mediocrity?
summary: This article reviews the Dell Latitude 5410 laptop, evaluating if it offers significant upgrades over its predecessor or remains a mediocre device. The review details specifications, performance benchmarks (Cinebench, GeekBench), and its suitability for corporate use, concluding it's a solid "fleet laptop" for business tasks rather than a high-performance personal device.

title: Nokia to cut up to 10,000 jobs worldwide
summary: Nokia plans to cut between 5,000 and 10,000 jobs globally over the next two years to reduce costs by €600m (£518m). The telecoms giant aims to invest in 5G, cloud computing, and digital infrastructure research to improve its performance against rivals. Job cuts are expected across various regions, with about 96 roles in the UK and 300 in Finland under threat.

title: Qualcomm Completes Acquisition of NUVIA
summary: Qualcomm Incorporated announced the completion of its acquisition of NUVIA for $1.4 billion. This acquisition aims to enhance Qualcomm's CPU roadmap, integrating next-generation CPUs across various products including smartphones, laptops, and automotive systems. The first Qualcomm Snapdragon platforms featuring these new internally designed CPUs are expected to sample in the second half of 2022.

title: Target, The 'Apple Experience' And Training
summary: This article discusses Target's strategy for staffing its new in-store Apple kiosks with specially trained employees, emphasizing the importance of knowledgeable staff for customer satisfaction and sales. It highlights how co-branding extends to employee training, crucial for retail partnerships and reducing employee turnover, while warning against exclusive training that could undermine collaborative culture.

title: Video Games & Esports: Building on 2020’s Rapid Growth
summary: The video game industry experienced significant growth in 2020, driven by the pandemic, new console releases, and the rise of social gaming, with total revenue reaching $175 billion. This article explores key trends poised to continue this expansion, including the increasing impact of digital distribution, the monetization strategies of free-to-play games, the evolution of social gaming into metaverse-like experiences, and the growing prominence of mobile gaming. It also highlights the role of game engines in facilitating development for smaller studios and concludes that the industry is set for continued strong performance and investor opportunities.

title: The 10 most innovative companies in consumer electronics
summary: This article highlights the top 10 most innovative companies in consumer electronics, showcasing how they adapted and thrived during the pandemic by releasing useful new products. It features companies like Corning, Apple, and Samsung alongside newer players such as Raspberry Pi, Tempo, and Aira. The piece details Corning's advancements in Gorilla Glass and Ceramic Shield, emphasizing their impact on device durability.

title: Tesla loses a third of its value for the third time in a year
summary: Tesla Inc.'s stock experienced its third significant drop in a year, losing a third of its value from its January record high, primarily due to investor concerns about rising interest rates affecting high-valuation stocks. The selloff wiped off nearly $300 billion from its market capitalization, moving it behind Facebook. This decline is more pronounced than other major tech companies, and its shares have steadily fallen since announcing a bitcoin purchase, even as bitcoin’s price climbed.

title: Brent Potts joined Airbnb, Inc. as Vice President of Community Support
summary: Brent Potts has joined Airbnb, Inc. as Vice President of Community Support, bringing extensive experience from Apple and Hewlett-Packard. His role will focus on enhancing support for Airbnb's global community of hosts and guests, aiming to further elevate the company's customer service standards. Potts previously led AppleCare divisions, streamlining customer support journeys for billions of customers.

title: KT and LG U+ buy into OneStore, the Google Play killer
summary: South Korean mobile carriers KT and LG U+ have acquired stakes in One Store, a local app market, joining SK Telecom to challenge the dominance of Google Play and Apple App Store. This strategic investment aims to bolster the domestic IT ecosystem and comes as foreign app markets face increasing criticism over their in-app payment policies. One Store saw a significant increase in transaction volume and turned a profit for the first time in 2020, benefiting from the controversy surrounding Google's 30 percent commission policy.

title: Goldman loses 4 executives in 3 days as Walmart fintech poaches Marcus chief
summary: Goldman Sachs is experiencing a significant executive exodus, with four executives departing in three days, including Marcus chief Omer Ismail and deputy David Stark who are joining Walmart's new fintech venture. Karen Seymour, Goldman's general counsel, is also leaving, and Eric Lane, co-head of asset management, is moving to Tiger Global Management. These departures highlight Walmart's serious entry into the fintech space and pose a challenge for Goldman's consumer banking division.

title: Target to open 'mini Apple shops' in select stores, offer more products online. Will your location get an upgrade?
summary: Target is introducing "mini Apple shops" within 17 select stores across the country, expanding Apple's physical footprint and offering an enhanced shopping experience. These dedicated spaces will showcase iPhones, iPads, Apple Watches, AirPods, and accessories, with Target tech employees receiving specialized training from Apple. The initiative aims to capitalize on the popularity of Apple products among Target shoppers and builds on Target's strategy of partnering with national brands to elevate its in-store experience.

title: American Express rolls out new Digital Receipts feature
summary: American Express has launched its new Digital Receipts feature, allowing customers to easily track and identify online purchases from merchants such as Google, Microsoft, Square, and Apple. This initiative aims to enhance transparency, reduce confusion over transactions, and provide greater account protection against fraudulent charges, especially given the surge in e-commerce. The service provides detailed purchase information directly through the Amex App or website.

title: Futu Holdings To Officially Launch Its Mobile Brokerage App – moomoo. Here’s What Singapore Investors Can Expect
summary: Futu Holdings is launching its mobile brokerage app, moomoo, in Singapore, offering low-cost access to U.S., Hong Kong, and Singapore stock markets. The app provides a fully digital investment experience with competitive commission fees, free Level 2 market data for US stocks, and tools for charting and analysis. New customers can receive a S$180 welcome bundle by signing up and depositing funds before March 8, 2021.

title: Design of first Sonos headphones detailed in new patent drawings
summary: New patent drawings reveal details of Sonos' first headphones, expected to launch later in 2021. These headphones are anticipated to compete with premium models from Bose, Sony, Apple, and others, potentially offering features like Wi-Fi connectivity and seamless hand-off with Sonos speakers, with an estimated price of $400-$450. The latest design shows a simpler headband attachment and the Sonos name on the ear cups.

title: Buffett’s Berkshire reveals major stakes in Verizon and Chevron
summary: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Inc. announced significant new investments, including an US$8.6-billion stake in Verizon Communications Inc. and a US$4.1-billion stake in Chevron Corp., as disclosed in a regulatory filing. To fund these and other new investments, Berkshire pared back holdings in companies like Apple Inc., while also reducing stakes in several banking rivals and increasing investments in pharmaceutical companies. These moves signal where Buffett and his portfolio managers see value and demonstrate efforts to deploy Berkshire's substantial cash hoard.

title: Corning and Schott battle over flexible glass handset displays
summary: Schott has successfully overturned two patents for flexible glass owned by Corning at the European Patent Office, intensifying their dispute over ultra-flexible glass for mobile devices. The outcome of this ongoing legal battle could significantly impact the production of flexible displays in the mobile industry. Corning continues to defend a third patent while Schott, a key supplier for Samsung Display's foldable phones, appears to be gaining ground.

title: Clubhouse says reviewing data protection practices after report points to flaws
summary: Clubhouse is reviewing its data protection practices following a report by the Stanford Internet Observatory that identified security flaws potentially exposing user data to the Chinese government. The audio app plans to implement stronger encryption and blocks to prevent data transmission to Chinese servers within 72 hours, spurred by the discovery that conversations by users in China could be transmitted via Chinese servers despite the app not being officially available there.

title: Years later, Bloomberg doubles down on disputed Supermicro supply chain hack story
summary: Bloomberg has published a new article, years after its initial disputed report, to double down on its claims that the Chinese state infiltrated Supermicro to plant secret chips on its motherboards. While Supermicro and other companies involved continue to deny these allegations, the new report offers additional context and quotes, alleging wider historical tampering and government investigations. Despite the ongoing denials and lack of official government confirmation, Bloomberg stands by its investigative journalism.

title: Ball Corp. sets retail launch of Rome, Ga.-made recyclable aluminum cups for early 2021
summary: Ball Corp. is set to launch its recyclable aluminum cups, manufactured in Rome, Ga., for retail in the first half of 2021. These cups, which are infinitely recyclable, have already been utilized at major sporting events like Super Bowl LIV and LV. This move expands their availability beyond limited pilot programs.

title: Twitter Shares and Social Media ETFs Balloon on Strong User Growth
summary: Twitter (NasdaqGS: TWTR) shares and social media ETFs, particularly the Global X Social Media ETF (SOCL), surged after Twitter reported strong user growth during the holiday quarter and into January, with revenue exceeding $1 billion. Despite this success, the company warned of potential user growth slowdowns due to post-pandemic normalization and possible impacts from Apple's privacy changes. Twitter also addressed the suspension of former President Donald Trump, noting it was well-received by advertisers.

title: A Look At 6 ETFs That Cover The Electric Vehicles Trend
summary: This article discusses the accelerating growth of the global electric vehicle (EV) market, highlighting record sales in late 2020 and forecasts for exponential growth from 2022 onwards. It recommends six electric vehicle-related ETFs, four of which cover EVs plus autonomous vehicles (AVs) and two that focus on EVs plus the EV supply chain, including battery makers and miners. The author emphasizes that the real EV boom has just begun and provides sales figures and market share percentages to support this trend.

title: The Q's Take It: Why This Pair of 'QQQ' ETFs Will Keep Performing
summary: This article discusses the continued strong performance of the Invesco QQQ Trust (QQQ) and the Invesco NASDAQ 100 ETF (QQQM), particularly in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic. It highlights how the Nasdaq 100's heavy allocation to technology, consumer services, and healthcare has driven outperformance compared to the S&P 500. The article also differentiates QQQ for traders and QQQM for buy-and-hold investors, emphasizing the growth component of the Nasdaq 100 for long-term strategies.

title: Here’s how the FAANG companies stack up this earnings season
summary: This article examines the performance of FAANG companies during the latest earnings season, highlighting their continued impressive growth in revenue and display of pricing power. Despite their large size and the challenges posed by the pandemic, these companies maintained successful growth strategies in the fourth quarter and throughout the previous year. The piece underscores the dominance of FAANG stocks in earnings reports.

title: Here’s how the FAANG companies stack up this earnings season
summary: The article discusses the strong performance of FAANG companies during the earnings season, specifically highlighting their impressive revenue growth and pricing power. This trend continued into the fourth quarter of the previous year and throughout the entire year, even amidst the pandemic. The author notes that these companies consistently deliver significant increases in revenue despite their large size.

title: Apple, Its Control Over the iPhone, and The Internet
summary: This article examines Apple's extensive control over the iPhone ecosystem and its implications for the internet, competition, and future digital economies. It argues that Apple's policies, while leading to success, inhibit innovation and create anti-competitive barriers for developers and users through its App Store, payment systems, and technology decisions. The author suggests regulatory intervention to force competition in app distribution and payments, allowing users to download apps from any source and developers to use alternative payment solutions.

title: Taiwan’s MediaTek launches 5G chip aimed at US
summary: MediaTek, a rival to Qualcomm and Samsung, has launched a new 5G chip, the M80, designed to capture market share in the United States. This new chip supports millimetre-wave technology, which is crucial for US carriers like Verizon, unlike its previous 5G chips that only supported the "sub-6" variant. The company aims to secure more contracts for US models, building on its progress with handset makers like Samsung and LG.

title: Climb On Board the ESG Megatrend with 'EFIV'
summary: The article highlights ESG investing as a "megatrend" and introduces the SPDR S&P 500 ESG ETF (EFIV) as a way for investors to access this market. It notes that President Joe Biden's administration is expected to provide tailwinds for ESG through its focus on clean energy and potential SEC reforms. EFIV invests in S&P 500 firms meeting sustainability criteria, maintaining similar industry group weights to the S&P 500, and has shown a 17% gain over the past year with a 0.10% expense ratio.

title: Bei Zhong, General Manager Asia–Pacific of LORD Corporation
summary: Bei Zhong, General Manager Asia–Pacific of LORD Corporation (now part of Parker Hannifin Corporation), emphasizes a leadership philosophy centered on driving culture, empowering teams, and fostering innovation. She highlights the importance of changing mindsets, understanding employee motivations, and building trust to achieve outstanding results. Zhong also discusses the significant growth potential in the electric vehicle market, where LORD Corporation is a key supplier, and addresses challenges like supply chain resilience and the accelerating pace of technological innovation.

title: Nestle, Nvidia, and the Changing Global Equity Markets
summary: The article analyzes the shifting dynamics of global equity markets over the past decade, characterized by the dominance of U.S. technology stocks like Nvidia, in contrast to traditional companies like Nestle. It highlights the increased concentration of U.S. market indexes in technology and consumer cyclical sectors, and discusses current valuation opportunities in non-U.S. markets and value sectors like energy.

title: UVXY ETF Is a Good Buy as Earnings and WSB Drive Volatility
summary: The article discusses why the ProShares Ultra VIX Short-Term Futures ETF (UVXY) is a good buy amidst rising market volatility. It explains that the VIX Index, which UVXY tracks, is rising due to the earnings season, fears of a stock market bubble, and the impact of the WallStreetBets Reddit community on certain stocks. The article suggests UVXY as a way to bet on continued volatility given its asset size, liquidity, and expense ratio compared to competitors.

title: Apple Just Got a Little Greener. The EFIV ETF Is All Ears
summary: Apple recently had its largest revenue quarter ever and is now incorporating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics into its executive compensation. This move makes Apple a greener investment, reinforcing its position as the top holding in the SPDR S&P 500 ESG ETF (EFIV). The EFIV ETF offers investors exposure to S&P 500 firms that meet specific sustainability criteria while maintaining similar overall industry group weights.

title: STMicroelectronics, Tesla and Apple: what happens when eMobility & 5G collide
summary: This article examines how STMicroelectronics' Q4 2020 results were bolstered by its key relationships with Tesla in e-mobility and Apple in 5G mobile and consumer markets. It highlights STMicroelectronics' dominance in Silicon Carbide (SiC) for electric vehicles, largely driven by Tesla's adoption, and its significant role in CMOS image sensors for Apple's 3D imaging and sensing applications. The article also discusses the company's strategies to address capacity constraints and maintain its market position against competitors.

title: AI fund that's beating S&P 500 has shifted into tech stocks
summary: A machine-guided fund, the AI Powered Equity ETF (AIEQ), has significantly shifted its holdings into technology stocks, now comprising over 37% of its portfolio. This move comes as the fund continues to outperform the S&P 500 Index, having risen 12% this year compared to the S&P 500's nearly 3% gain. The fund has also halved its industrial exposure and doubled its position in Tesla Inc., while significantly reducing its Apple Inc. holdings.

title: The Tech Sector Today: Not the Bubble of the 1990s
summary: The technology sector, while performing strongly, is fundamentally different from the 1990s bubble. The Invesco DWA Technology Momentum ETF (PTF) is highlighted as an attractive option, leveraging relative strength investing. Momentum strategies such as PTF are less volatile now compared to the 2000 tech bubble and can offer diversification benefits to portfolios.

title: Smartphone audio is important, and here’s what it takes to build the best
summary: This article discusses the importance of audio quality in smartphones and the technology behind building superior smartphone speakers. It highlights the role of high-quality amplifier chips, particularly Class H amplifiers, in enabling clear, powerful, and distortion-free audio. The piece also mentions companies like Cirrus Logic and their CS35L40 and CS35L41 amplifier ICs, which are used in many high-profile smartphones to achieve top audio performance.

title: Qualcomm to supply General Motors with 'cockpit' chips for next generation vehicles
summary: Qualcomm Inc announced a deal to supply General Motors Co with a range of chips for its next generation of vehicles. The agreement includes Qualcomm's "cockpit" chips for in-dashboard systems and automated driver assistance system chips. Qualcomm's Snapdragon Ride driver-assistance computer is also expected to be in a production vehicle in 2022.

title: Clarivate Launches Web of Science My Research Assistant Mobile Application
summary: Clarivate Plc launched Web of Science My Research Assistant, a new mobile application designed to help scientific researchers search, save, and share publication records from the Web of Science citation index. The app offers features like personalized feeds and reading lists, with both free and unlimited functionality available depending on the user's institutional affiliation. This initiative aims to improve the researcher experience by providing a more personalized service and fostering collaboration within the science community.

title: Apple, Southern Company to invest $25 million for AUC’s Propel Center
summary: Apple and Southern Company are investing $25 million each to establish the Propel Center, a global innovation and learning hub for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), at the Atlanta University Center. This initiative, part of Apple's Racial Equity and Justice Initiative, aims to provide innovative curricula, technological support, career opportunities, and fellowship programs to promote diverse leaders and address systemic racism. The center will focus on various fields, including agricultural technologies, social justice, entertainment arts, app development, and augmented reality, to help minority students excel in the tech industry.

title: Netflix will consider buybacks as it returns to positive cash flow after 2021
summary: Netflix announced it expects to be cash-flow positive after 2021 and will no longer require external financing, ending a decade of significant debt. The company also stated it would consider share buybacks, a practice not seen since 2011. This shift validates Netflix's long-term content spending strategy and comes as its market capitalization has grown significantly.

title: Online TV Streaming Service Market: Strong Growth Continues
summary: The online TV streaming service market is experiencing strong growth, driven by technological advancements, urbanization, increased internet/mobile subscriptions, and rising disposable incomes. Key players like Netflix have significantly expanded their subscriber base. The COVID-19 pandemic further accelerated demand, leading to a surge in subscriptions for major streaming platforms.

title: Conservative ETF Reshuffles, ‘QQQ’ Sibs Hit $1B
summary: The American Conservative Values ETF (ACVF) has ceased new purchases of Apple, Amazon, and Google stock due to their perceived censorship of free speech, following their blocking of social media platform Parler. Meanwhile, Invesco's NASDAQ 100 ETF (QQQM) and Invesco NASDAQ Next Gen 100 ETF (QQQJ) have jointly surpassed $1 billion in assets under management in just three months, marking Invesco's most successful launch ever.

title: Intel CEO Bob Swan to Be Replaced by VMware Chief
summary: Intel Corp. Chief Executive Officer Bob Swan will be replaced by VMware Inc. CEO Pat Gelsinger, who is returning to Intel more than a decade after leaving. This leadership change comes as Intel faces manufacturing delays, increased competition, and customers designing their own chips. Gelsinger's appointment is seen as a move to bring back technical and home-grown leadership to address the company's challenges.

title: Qualcomm eyes challenge to Apple, Intel with $1.4 billion deal for chip startup
summary: Qualcomm Inc. announced its acquisition of Nuvia Inc., a chip startup founded by former Apple Inc. executives, for $1.4 billion. This strategic move aims to integrate Nuvia's technology into Qualcomm's smartphone, laptop, and automotive processors, challenging Apple and Intel in chip performance. The deal also represents Qualcomm's effort to lessen its reliance on Arm Ltd. and enhance its custom core designs for various applications.

title: Qualcomm eyes challenge to Apple, Intel with $1.4 billion deal for chip startup
summary: Qualcomm Inc announced its acquisition of Nuvia Inc, a chip startup founded by former Apple executives, for $1.4 billion. This move aims to enhance Qualcomm's chip performance in smartphones, laptops, and automotive processors, challenging rivals like Apple and Intel. The deal also helps Qualcomm reduce its reliance on Arm Ltd's licensed technology by incorporating Nuvia's custom core designs.

title: Southern Company joins Apple in announcing launch of new digital learning hub, global headquarters for innovation for HBCUs
summary: Southern Company and Apple have partnered to launch the Propel Center, a digital learning hub and innovation headquarters for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) in Atlanta, Georgia. Both companies are contributing $25 million each to establish the center, which aims to foster Black entrepreneurship, provide technology resources, and prepare HBCU students for future careers. The initiative builds on previous collaborations to advance educational equity and address underrepresentation in STEM fields.

title: The Walt Disney Company
summary: This page from Newsweek compiles various news articles related to The Walt Disney Company. It covers topics ranging from leadership changes, theme park updates, streaming content, financial performance, and political disputes primarily with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, showcasing a wide array of company-related news.

title: Rock star chip designer Jim Keller joins Tenstorrent
summary: Legendary computer chip designer Jim Keller has joined Toronto startup Tenstorrent Inc. as its new president and chief technology officer. Keller, known for his work at AMD, Apple, and Tesla, will guide Tenstorrent in its mission to create a machine learning training chip that utilizes software to optimize computing power and increase efficiency, challenging established players like Intel, AMD, and Nvidia.

title: Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf to retire; Cristiano Amon will replace him
summary: Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf will retire in June 2021 after 26 years with the company, with company President Cristiano Amon set to succeed him. Mollenkopf led Qualcomm through significant challenges, including legal battles and a hostile takeover attempt, while Amon is tasked with leading the company through the 5G transition and expanding into new markets beyond smartphones. Amon, who has been with Qualcomm since 1995, is expected to continue the company's focus on product roadmap and leverage 5G opportunities.

title: Interested In Apple But Not Its Volatility? 2 ETFs To Preserve Stability
summary: This article suggests two ETFs for investors interested in Apple's potential returns but wary of its volatility. It highlights the iShares Russell Top 200 Growth ETF (IWY) and the Fidelity MSCI Information Technology Index ETF (FTEC) as ways to gain exposure to Apple and other growth/tech companies while potentially mitigating short-term price swings. The article details the holdings, performance, and financial metrics of both ETFs.

title: Qualcomm Chief Executive Steve Mollenkopf to Step Down
summary: Qualcomm announced that CEO Steve Mollenkopf will step down in June, after leading the company through a period of significant growth in smartphone sales despite legal battles with Apple. Cristiano Amon, the current president, will succeed Mollenkopf and aims to capitalize on the increasing demand for 5G phones. Mollenkopf will remain an adviser for a period after the transition.

title: Cable One Preps IP-Based Sparklight TV
summary: Sparklight, a subsidiary of Cable One, is set to launch Sparklight TV, an IP-based TV service, in early 2021. This transition to IPTV aims to reclaim spectrum, freeing up network capacity to enhance Gigabit offerings and establish a 10G technology platform. The service will be accessible via streaming apps on platforms like Amazon Fire TV, Android TV, and Apple TV.

title: Chip giant Qualcomm names President Amon as new CEO
summary: Qualcomm Inc. has named its president and chip division head, Cristiano Amon, as its new chief executive, replacing Steven Mollenkopf, effective June 30. Amon has been with the company since 1995 and became president in 2018, overseeing the chip division and guiding the company's expansion into new areas like 5G infrastructure, automotive computers, and personal computers. Mollenkopf, a 26-year veteran, successfully navigated Qualcomm through significant crises including a hostile takeover attempt, an antitrust challenge, and a legal battle with Apple.

title: The TDVG ETF Is a Stellar Choice for Dividend Growth
summary: The TDVG ETF is highlighted as a strong option for investors seeking dividend growth in 2021, given forecasts for increased S&P 500 payouts. This actively managed ETF focuses on companies with a history and expectation of increasing dividends, offering a compelling strategy in a low-interest-rate environment. Companies are showing renewed confidence in dividend growth, further supporting the investment thesis for TDVG.

title: Apple Veterans’ Lidar Startup Adds $200 Million to SPAC Deal
summary: Aeva, a lidar startup founded by former Apple engineers, is set to receive an additional $200 million investment from Sylebra Capital Management, boosting its total proceeds from a SPAC deal to $563 million. This funding increases Aeva's war chest ahead of its public listing via a reverse merger with InterPrivate Acquisition Corp., highlighting strong investor interest in next-generation auto-related technologies.

title: Apple loses copyright claims in lawsuit against U.S. security bug startup
summary: A federal judge in Florida dismissed Apple Inc.'s copyright infringement claims against Corellium LLC, a startup whose software helps security researchers find vulnerabilities in Apple products. The judge ruled Corellium's software, which emulates iOS, amounted to "fair use" as it was "transformative" and served a public benefit by aiding in the discovery of security flaws. Apple may still pursue a separate federal law claim regarding circumvention of security measures.

title: Exclusive: Hedge fund Third Point urges Intel to explore deal options
summary: Activist hedge fund Third Point LLC, which has amassed a nearly $1 billion stake in Intel Corp, is urging the U.S. chipmaker to explore strategic alternatives, including whether it should keep chip design and production under one roof. Third Point CEO Daniel Loeb sent a letter to Intel Chairman Omar Ishrak, calling for immediate action to boost the company's position, address "human capital management issue," and consider divesting failed acquisitions. This push comes as Intel has lost market share to competitors like TSMC, Samsung, and AMD, and its stock has underperformed the Nasdaq Composite Index.
