title: Intel shares rise after Third Point urges chipmaker to explore strategic alternatives as market share deteriorates
summary: Hedge fund Third Point, which recently acquired a significant stake in Intel, is urging the chipmaker's board to explore strategic alternatives due to deteriorating market share against rivals like TSMC, Samsung, and AMD. Third Point highlighted concerns about Intel's loss of manufacturing leadership and its impact on U.S. national security. Intel has stated it welcomes input from investors to enhance shareholder value.

title: Tim Cook's Response to Facebook's Attack Is the Best Example of Emotional Intelligence I've Ever Seen
summary: This article praises Tim Cook's response to Facebook's public attack on Apple's privacy changes in iOS 14, highlighting it as an exemplary demonstration of emotional intelligence. Cook's concise and measured 47-word statement effectively clarified Apple's position without engaging in emotional or argumentative language, contrasting sharply with Facebook's extensive advertising campaign. The author argues that Cook's approach serves as a perfect model for leaders facing public criticism.

title: Time Magazine to be sold to Salesforce Billionaire Marc Benioff
summary: Marc Benioff, co-founder of Salesforce, and his wife Lynne, are purchasing Time magazine from Meredith Corp. for $190 million in cash. Benioff becomes the latest tech billionaire to acquire an iconic media brand, emphasizing journalistic integrity and a desire to preserve the publication's legacy. The Benioffs intend to keep Time's editorial independence and help it transition into the digital world while maintaining its print foundation.

title: Alibaba's Only Stock Split Was Out of the Ordinary
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. executed an eight-for-one stock split on July 15, 2019, to increase the number of available shares and raise capital for growth. This split coincided with a secondary listing on a Hong Kong exchange, which diluted shares but helped Alibaba secure the largest IPO listing of 2019. Despite its significance, the secondary listing caused the stock split to go largely unnoticed by American investors.

title: Elon Musk says had once reached out to Apple for acquiring Tesla
summary: Elon Musk revealed he tried to discuss a potential acquisition of Tesla by Apple during Tesla's "darkest days of the Model 3 program," but Apple CEO Tim Cook refused the meeting. This happened as Apple is reportedly looking to produce a passenger vehicle by 2024 with new battery technology, which Musk commented on. Tesla has since overcome its production issues and recently joined the S&P 500.

title: Walmart Sued, Apple Car, Riot Blockchain Jumps 32%
summary: The Justice Department is suing Walmart for allegedly contributing to the opioid crisis, causing a slight dip in Walmart's stock. Meanwhile, Riot Blockchain's stock surged over 32% after announcing a massive purchase of new mining machines, and Apple's stock rose on renewed speculation about its potential entry into the automotive industry with an "Apple Car." The stock market overall experienced a slight downturn despite the signing of a new pandemic relief package.

title: Rare-Earth Elements: Will China Continue Its Market Dominance?
summary: China currently dominates the global market for rare-earth elements, essential for various high-tech and military applications, leveraging decades of strategic investment. The article explores whether recent US efforts and alliances with countries like Japan and Australia can challenge China's market dominance, particularly given China's "Made in China 2025" initiative and temporary pandemic-induced price fluctuations. Despite challenges, rare-earth prices are expected to recover, and investment opportunities exist through ETFs like VanEck Vectors Rare Earth/Strategic Metals ETF (NYSEArca: REMX).

title: Tesla stock slides on first day in S&P 500
summary: Tesla's shares fell over 6% on its first day in the S&P 500, influenced by concerns about a new Covid-19 variant, disappointment over a stimulus deal, and news of Apple's self-driving car plans. The drop followed a significant pre-inclusion surge, with analysts noting similar post-inclusion declines for other high-profile S&P 500 additions. Analysts also voiced concerns about the stock's valuation and increasing competition in the EV market.

title: Apple to Suspend New Orders to Wistron After India Workers Riot
summary: Apple Inc. has placed its Indian supplier Wistron Corp. on probation and will suspend new orders following labor practice lapses that led to worker riots. Preliminary investigations revealed that Wistron, the first Apple supplier to produce iPhones in India, failed to properly manage working hours, resulting in payment delays for some employees in October and November. Apple will withhold new orders until these issues are resolved.

title: Tesla shares jump to record high ahead of S&P 500 debut
summary: Shares of Tesla Inc. surged to a record high on Friday, driven by anticipation of its inclusion in the S&P 500 index. The electric carmaker, led by Elon Musk, will become the most valuable company ever admitted to the benchmark, accounting for over 1% of its value. This event prompted index-tracking funds to buy an estimated $85 billion worth of Tesla shares, influencing significant trading volume and price movements.

title: Yext CEO Howard Lerman returns to the OMR Podcast
summary: Yext CEO Howard Lerman returned to the OMR Podcast to discuss the current search landscape and the importance for companies to provide search alternatives to Google. Lerman emphasizes that brands need to optimize their websites for search to keep customers from going to Google and finding competitors, highlighting Yext's mission to revolutionize company search functions. He also discusses the company's $2 billion valuation.

title: Apple (AAPL) iPhone Subcontractor Rocked by Worker Riot
summary: A worker riot occurred at an iPhone assembly plant in India owned by Apple subcontractor Wistron, sparked by grievances over unpaid wages and working hours. The incident caused significant damage and led to arrests, impacting Apple's supply chain and potential production targets for 2021. This event highlights the risks and challenges of outsourcing production for cost-cutting to subcontractors.

title: UnitedHealthcare Introduces Enhancements for Wearable Device Well-being Program, Including Access to Apple Fitness+ at No Additional Cost
summary: UnitedHealthcare has enhanced its Motion wearable device well-being program, offering eligible members at least six months of Apple Fitness+ at no additional cost starting in 2021. The program also introduces new ways to earn financial rewards for various physical activities beyond walking, including cycling and elliptical use, with the goal of making activity goals more accessible. These enhancements aim to provide digital resources and financial incentives to help members improve their health and well-being.

title: I tried out Fitness+, Apple’s polished new exercise subscription
summary: The author reviews Apple's new Fitness+ connected workout service, highlighting its polished design, rich content library, and seamless integration with Apple Watch. Despite being impressed with its technical and design aspects, the author notes that some "For Beginners" workouts might not fully cater to complete novices in certain exercise types. Overall, Fitness+ is presented as a valuable option for at-home exercise, especially for existing Apple Watch users.

title: Oracle is the latest Silicon Valley company to head for the hills — of Austin
summary: Oracle Corp. announced its decision to move its corporate headquarters from Redwood City, California, to Austin, Texas, following a trend of companies and executives relocating from Silicon Valley. This move aligns with a new flexible employee work location policy and positions Oracle for growth in a business-friendly state. Governor Greg Abbott lauded the relocation, emphasizing Texas's appeal for business, jobs, and opportunity, with other tech giants like Tesla and HP Enterprise also making similar moves or expanding in the state.

title: Broadcom names Kirsten Spears as CFO
summary: Broadcom Inc. announced the appointment of Kirsten Spears as its new chief financial officer, effective immediately, replacing Tom Krause. The company also forecast first-quarter revenue above Wall Street estimates, driven by anticipated higher demand from Apple Inc. due to the rollout of 5G technology. Shares of Broadcom were down nearly 1% in extended trading following the announcement.

title: Hyatt CEO Mark Hoplamazian named Board of Directors Chair at American Hotel & Lodging Association (AHLA)
summary: Mark Hoplamazian, President and CEO of Hyatt Hotels Corporation, has been named Chair of the Board of Directors at the American Hotel & Lodging Association (AHLA). The AHLA also announced its 2021 officers and executive committee, highlighting a diverse group of industry leaders. Justin Knight was named vice chair, Leslie D. Hale as secretary/treasurer, and Greg Juceam continues as chair of the AHLA Foundation Board of Trustees.

title: Adobe Stock Looks Like a Buy Before Its Earnings Release
summary: Adobe stock has gained over 47% YTD and is considered a potential buy before its Q4 earnings release on Dec. 9. Despite a recent cool-down from its 52-week highs, the company's consistent revenue growth and attractive PEG ratio suggest it could be a long-term investment, especially if positive earnings and guidance are provided. Analysts anticipate a median target price of $560, indicating a 15.2% premium over current prices.

title: FedEx’s ShopRunner acquisition provides access to e-commerce marketplace data
summary: FedEx announced its acquisition of ShopRunner, an e-commerce platform, to enhance its digital and logistics capabilities and gain access to valuable e-commerce marketplace data. The deal, subject to regulatory approval, is expected to close by the end of 2020. This acquisition will help FedEx better understand and serve the e-commerce market, especially important with the surge in online shopping due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Judge throws out Trump rules limiting skilled-worker visas
summary: A federal judge in California has struck down two Trump administration rules that aimed to significantly reduce the number of H-1B visas issued to skilled foreign workers. The judge ruled that the government failed to follow proper transparency procedures and that its argument of an emergency response to COVID-19 job losses was unconvincing. This decision is seen as a significant relief for companies and current H-1B visa holders.

title: Qualcomm taps Samsung to make new flagship 5G smartphone chips
summary: Qualcomm announced its new flagship 5G smartphone chip, the Snapdragon 888, which will be manufactured by Samsung Electronics. This chip features enhanced gaming and photo abilities and is expected to be in high-end Android phones from brands like Xiaomi and LG in Q1 next year. Samsung secured the manufacturing contract on its 5-nanometer process, a first for Qualcomm's flagship chip.

title: Why Dimensional Fund Advisors is converting six of its mutual funds to the ETF format
summary: Dimensional Fund Advisors is converting six mutual funds to ETFs as part of an industry-first move, building on the success of its newly launched transparent, actively managed ETFs like DFAU and DFAI. The conversion aims to offer investors the benefits of indexing combined with active management, as requested by financial professionals, and capitalizes on the strong performance of value stocks.

title: Cirrus Logic enters Apple’s Smart Watch world
summary: Cirrus Logic has entered Apple's Smart Watch supply chain, supplying the multichannel amplifier for the new Apple Watch Series 6, a role previously held by Dialog Semiconductor. The latest Apple Watch Series 6 features an elaborate pulse oximeter and heart rate sensor, alongside a UWB module with Apple's U1 chip, but sees the elimination of Force Touch technology. These findings come from a teardown report by System Plus Consulting, highlighting significant component changes in the new smartwatch.

title: Apple Hires Prominent Venture Capitalist for App Store Role
summary: Apple Inc. has hired Josh Elman, a former venture capitalist from Greylock Partners, for a role rumored to be focused on the App Store. Elman, known for early investments in Discord and the precursor to TikTok, will concentrate on app discovery for customers and step back from his investing and corporate board positions. This move suggests Apple's continued focus on enhancing the App Store experience.

title: New CEO of the Year: Christy Wyatt’s focus on customers turned Absolute Software’s fortunes around
summary: Christy Wyatt's leadership as CEO of Absolute Software Corp. has led to a significant turnaround for the cybersecurity company. By focusing on customer needs and emphasizing the company's unique "self-healing" technology, she improved financial performance, customer acquisition, and market perception. Wyatt's strategic approach, stemming from a diverse background in tech, has positioned Absolute Software for continued growth, especially with the increased reliance on remote work.

title: Should you invest in technology sector funds?
summary: This article discusses the performance and prospects of technology sector funds in India, highlighting their strong returns during the pandemic and the factors influencing their growth. It explores investment options including domestic and international tech funds, the outlook for Indian IT firms, and crucial risks and investment strategies investors should consider, such as staggering investments via SIPs.

title: AMC Plus Launches on Roku Channel
summary: AMC Networks announced that its premium streaming service, AMC Plus, is now available on The Roku Channel. The service, priced at $8.99 a month, offers original programming from AMC's cable networks and streaming services, including "The Walking Dead Universe" and "Mad Men." This launch expands AMC Plus's distribution, following recent additions to Prime Video Channels, Apple TV channels, Comcast, Dish, and Sling TV.

title: Apple’s global security chief and two members of Sheriff’s office indicted for alleged bribery
summary: Apple’s global head of security, Thomas Moyer, and two members of the Santa Clara County Sheriff’s office have been indicted for an alleged bribery scheme. Moyer is accused of promising to donate 200 iPads to the sheriff's office in exchange for concealed weapons licenses for Apple employees. The district attorney's office claims Undersheriff Rick Sung and Captain James Jensen withheld the licenses until they received a valuable offer.

title: Universal Electronics Offers Alternative Apple TV Remote to Cable Companies
summary: Universal Electronics has unveiled a new remote for Apple TV 4K, designed for cable, satellite, and MVPD customers. This alternative remote uses Bluetooth Low Energy and Infrared for universal control, includes Siri integration, a program guide button, and traditional media controls. It will be offered directly to cable companies rather than consumers, targeting the growing number of MVPDs providing Apple TV 4K to subscribers.

title: The Apple TV remote has yet another alternate option that includes buttons
summary: Universal Electronics (UEI) has introduced a new Apple TV remote alternative designed for cable companies, addressing user frustration with the standard Apple TV remote's touchpad controls. This new remote features physical buttons, Siri voice command capability, backlit keys, and universal control for other entertainment devices. It will be available through cable, satellite, and MVPD customers starting next year, rather than directly to consumers.

title: Why Teradyne’s offerings provide value to end-user markets
summary: This article examines Teradyne's (TER) diverse product line and how it delivers value to its customer base across various end-user markets. It details Teradyne's semiconductor test platforms like FLEX, J750, and Magnum, and how they cater to industries such as mobile, automotive, and data storage. The article also highlights Teradyne's key customers and its presence in semiconductor-focused ETFs.

title: Applied Materials’s position in the semiconductor space
summary: Applied Materials (AMAT) generates significant revenue from leading semiconductor companies like Samsung, Intel, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. The company's revenue growth is driven by orders from smaller customers and its diverse product lines, though it faces geographical risk due to a substantial portion of its revenue coming from Taiwan. The article highlights AMAT's ability to increase revenue and backlog despite chip capital expenditure forecasts remaining constant.

title: Why IBM’s Global Business Services Failed to Grow
summary: IBM's Global Business Services (GBS) segment experienced a decline in revenue in fiscal 1Q16, despite strong growth in its Strategic Imperatives and Cloud sectors. To counter this, IBM acquired several companies in the digital agency and marketing space and partnered with Apple and Twitter to strengthen its presence in software, cloud, and big data.

title: Apple to Pay $113 Million Settlement Over ‘Batterygate’ Scandal
summary: Apple has agreed to pay a $113 million settlement to 33 U.S. states over "batterygate" allegations, where the company was accused of deliberately slowing down older iPhones to encourage purchases of newer models. In addition to this, Apple is also liable for up to $500 million in a separate class-action lawsuit. The company had previously apologized for the performance issues, attributing them to a power management feature, and had offered discounted battery replacements.
source: Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project | OCCRP
source_domain: Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project | OCCRP

title: Nvidia, Epic to bring 'Fortnite' back to iPhones in 'near future'
summary: Nvidia and Epic Games are collaborating to bring "Fortnite" back to Apple iPhones through Nvidia's GeForce NOW streaming game service in the near future. The game was removed from Apple's App Store in August due to Epic's billing system, which violated Apple's rules. This return route bypasses Apple's App Store rules by utilizing the iPhone's Safari web browser.

title: AG Yost Announces $113 Million Settlement with Apple Over iPhone Throttling
summary: Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost, along with over 30 other attorneys general, announced a $113 million settlement with Apple, Inc. regarding Apple’s 2016 decision to throttle iPhone speeds. The attorneys general alleged that Apple concealed battery issues leading to unexpected shutdowns, profiting by selling new iPhones after purposefully slowing older devices. As part of the settlement, Apple will pay Ohio $4.3 million and must provide truthful information to consumers about iPhone battery health and performance.

title: Attorney General Josh Stein Announces $113 Million Settlement with Apple over iPhone Throttling
summary: Attorney General Josh Stein announced a $113 million multistate settlement with Apple Inc. regarding its 2016 decision to throttle iPhone speeds. North Carolina will receive over $2.7 million from the settlement. The agreement requires Apple to provide truthful information to consumers about iPhone battery health, performance, and power management.

title: Apple, U.S. states reach $113 million settlement on iPhone throttling
summary: Apple Inc. has agreed to pay $113 million to settle allegations from 33 U.S. states and the District of Columbia that it intentionally slowed down iPhones to mask battery issues and prompt users to buy new devices. The settlement, which includes an agreement for Apple to provide truthful information about iPhone power management, is separate from a previous $500 million class-action settlement. States contended Apple acted deceptively by not disclosing the throttling or offering battery replacements.

title: Apple Agrees To Pay $113 Million To Settle 'Batterygate' Case Over iPhone Slowdowns
summary: Apple has agreed to pay $113 million to settle consumer fraud lawsuits with more than 30 states over its "batterygate" controversy, where it secretly slowed down older iPhones. The settlement also requires Apple to be more transparent about software updates affecting battery life. This follows a previous agreement in March where Apple agreed to pay up to $500 million directly to consumers.

title: Apple to lower App Store fees for small developers, but some critics not impressed
summary: Apple announced a new program to lower its App Store commission to 15% for software developers who make $1 million US or less in proceeds annually. While some hail this as a "huge win" for smaller developers, critics like Epic Games CEO Tim Sweeney and Spotify Technology SA dismissed it as "window dressing" and a calculated move to preserve Apple's monopoly and divide app creators. The change affects a large percentage of developers but a small portion of Apple's overall App Store revenue.

title: Apple (AAPL) to Cut App Store Fees in Half to 15% for Most Developers
summary: Apple Inc. is set to cut App Store fees in half, to 15% from 30%, for developers who generate up to $1 million in annual revenue from their apps, effective January 1. This change, part of the App Store Small Business Program, marks the biggest alteration to the store’s revenue model since its 2008 launch and will apply to the vast majority of developers, though major apps like Netflix and Spotify will not be affected. Some developers, such as Spotify, have called the change "window dressing."

title: Who’s a Very Good Pandemic Business? Chewy Is. Oh, Yes It Is
summary: Chewy (CHWY) has experienced phenomenal growth in 2020, becoming a top pandemic business as pet care surged. CEO Sumit Singh's 2019 compensation of $108.2 million placed him among the highest-paid executives, despite the company not yet achieving profitability in its nine years of existence. This success highlights the booming online pet supply market.

title: Garmin Pilot adds graphical airspace & obstacle NOTAMS
summary: Garmin International Inc. has introduced new features to its Garmin Pilot application for Apple mobile devices, enhancing pre-flight planning and in-flight situational awareness with graphical airspace and obstacle NOTAMs. The update also includes an improved user interface for Profile View, offering quicker access to critical flight information like weather and PIREPs. This release, version 10.3, is available immediately for Apple mobile devices, with subscription options after a 30-day free trial.

title: BlackBerry looks to sell majority of its patents as it refocuses
summary: BlackBerry Ltd. is reportedly looking to sell the majority of its 38,000 patents, a move that could generate over US$450-million but also raise concerns about Canadian intellectual property leaving the country. This comes as the company continues to pivot away from its smartphone business towards cybersecurity and automotive operating systems, relying on patent licensing for a significant portion of its revenue. Industry experts are debating the implications for Canada's innovation strategy and standing in the global patent market.

title: American Express members can add card to Apple Pay after approval
summary: American Express has introduced a new feature that allows approved card members to add their new card to Apple Wallet immediately after application, streamlining the process for using Apple Pay. This integration builds on Amex's existing Instant Card Number system but offers automated provisioning and immediate access to membership benefits. The feature is currently available to U.S. customers applying for new consumer cards via AmericanExpress.com.

title: Infographic: Gaming industry revenues grow 8.3% worldwide, pandemic accelerating upward trend
summary: The gaming industry is experiencing significant growth, with global revenues forecast to increase by 8.3% to $178.2 billion in 2021. This upward trend has been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to increased spending by gamers, especially in mobile gaming. The industry is also proving to be crisis-resistant, with gaming shares performing well on the stock exchange.

title: American Express launches support for adding new cards to Apple Pay instantly after approval
summary: American Express has launched a new feature allowing customers to instantly add newly approved credit cards to Apple Pay. This development allows American Express to compete with Apple Card's instant access feature, offering immediate use of new cards in retail stores, online, and in-app for U.S. consumer credit card customers.

title: 115 Amazon lobbyists. 1 works on climate
summary: Despite Amazon's public stance on climate action and its "Climate Pledge," an analysis reveals that only one out of its 115 lobbyists is focused on environmental issues. This raises questions about the company's commitment, with critics suggesting it may be "greenwashing." Other tech giants like Facebook also show similar discrepancies, while Microsoft, Apple, and Google appear to align their lobbying efforts more closely with their climate concerns.

title: How Apple built its own chip empire and gave Intel the boot
summary: Apple is transitioning its MacBooks from Intel chips to in-house silicon, marking a major milestone for the company's hardware and software integration. This move stems from a long-term strategy that began with the acquisition of P.A. Semi in 2008, enabling Apple to develop its own A-series chips for mobile devices. The decision was driven by improved performance of Apple's chips, better chip economics by outsourcing production, and greater control over hardware-software integration.

title: Apple unleashes M1
summary: Apple announced the M1 chip, its first chip designed specifically for the Mac, delivering industry-leading performance, powerful features, and incredible efficiency. The M1 chip integrates numerous technologies into a single SoC, featuring an 8-core CPU, the world's fastest integrated graphics, and a 16-core Neural Engine for accelerated machine learning. This launch marks the beginning of a two-year transition for the Mac to Apple silicon, with macOS Big Sur optimized to leverage the M1's capabilities.

title: Apple’s New MacBooks (and Mac Mini) Are Powered By iPhone DNA
summary: Apple announced new Mac desktop and laptop computers powered by its homemade M1 chip, an ARM-based design similar to those found in iPhones and iPads. This marks a significant shift from Intel processors, promising benefits like improved battery life, graphics, and machine learning capabilities, along with compatibility for iOS and iPadOS apps. The initial models include new MacBook Air ($999), MacBook Pro ($1,299), and Mac Mini ($699) offerings.

title: Apple unveils M1, the 1st in-house chip for Mac computers
summary: Apple unveiled its first in-house "Apple Silicon" chip, dubbed the M1, at its final event of 2020, powering new MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, and Mac Mini models. This new chip aims to significantly improve performance, speed, and battery life for Macs, marking a major step for Apple to gain more control over its hardware development. The company plans to transition its entire computer lineup to Apple Silicon chips within a few years.

title: Apple's new Macs could revive the PC chip wars, benefit Qualcomm: Analysts
summary: Apple is expected to unveil new Mac computers using its own in-house Arm-based processor chips, a move that could disrupt the PC chip market currently dominated by Intel and AMD. This shift could benefit companies like Qualcomm, which has been developing Arm-based processors for Windows PCs. Analysts suggest that Apple's entry into this market could accelerate the adoption of Arm-based PCs, despite challenges related to software compatibility.

title: Apple's new Macs could revive the PC chip wars, analysts say
summary: Apple's expected unveiling of new Mac computers with in-house processor chips based on Arm Ltd. technology could re-ignite competition in the PC chip market, currently dominated by Intel and Advanced Micro Devices. This shift marks a departure from Apple's nearly 15-year relationship with Intel and could benefit companies like Qualcomm, which has been adapting Arm-based processors for Windows PCs. Analysts believe Apple's entry will accelerate the adoption of Arm-based PCs, although challenges remain for software compatibility.

title: FAANG stands for five very successful tech companies that can move the stock market — here's what to know about investing in them
summary: The article defines FAANG as an acronym representing Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, and Google, five influential tech companies that significantly impact the stock market. It details their historical performance, their combined market capitalization, and how investors can invest in them, either individually or through various tech and index funds. The piece emphasizes their role as modern-day blue-chip stocks and their substantial impact on the S&P 500 and the broader US economy.

title: Ink-Stained Wretches: The Battle for the Soul of Digital Freedom Taking Place Inside Your Printer
summary: This article criticizes HP's aggressive business practices in the printer industry, detailing how the company has shifted from innovation to exploiting customers through printer ink policies. It highlights HP's conversion of a "Free ink for life" plan to a paid subscription and its use of "security updates" to block third-party ink cartridges. The piece argues that HP's tactics reflect a broader trend among "smart" gadget manufacturers to redefine ownership and restrict user choice.

title: Carl Icahn boosts Xerox stake to over 14%
summary: Billionaire activist investor Carl Icahn increased his stake in Xerox Holdings Corp to approximately 14.4% as of November 5th. This move comes months after he supported Xerox's unsuccessful attempt to acquire HP Inc. Following the news of Icahn's increased stake, Xerox's shares rose 3.4% in extended trading.

title: Apple must face shareholder lawsuit over CEO Cook's China sales comments
summary: A U.S. District Judge ruled that Apple Inc. must face a class-action lawsuit from shareholders accusing CEO Tim Cook of concealing declining iPhone demand in China, which led to significant investor losses. The lawsuit stems from Cook's 2018 comments assuring investors about China sales, shortly before Apple drastically cut its revenue forecast due to trade tensions impacting the Chinese economy. The judge found it plausible that Cook's statements were misleading and that he likely knew about the risks.

title: Austin’s Cirrus Logic announces CEO change
summary: Austin-based chipmaker Cirrus Logic announced that company president John Forsyth will become CEO next year, replacing longtime chief executive Jason Rhode. The announcement coincided with Cirrus Logic reporting strong quarterly earnings, surpassing Wall Street expectations, largely driven by smartphone component sales. The company's stock rose in after-hours trading following the news.

title: Apple loses $450b in value on iPhone woes
summary: Apple Inc. has lost $450 billion in market value since its peak last month, with a recent 5.6% drop wiping out over $120 billion. The decline follows disappointing iPhone sales that missed analysts' estimates and a lack of holiday quarter guidance. This slump, along with other tech giants' performance, is raising concerns about future growth in the sector.

title: Apple's late iPhone launch temporarily wiped $100 billion off its stock value
summary: A delayed launch of new 5G iPhones led to Apple Inc.'s steepest quarterly drop in iPhone sales in two years, causing its stock value to temporarily fall by $100 billion. Despite strong sales in other product categories like Macs and AirPods, iPhone sales dropped significantly, particularly in China, but CEO Tim Cook expressed optimism for a recovery in the fiscal first quarter due to the new 5G devices. The company's dependence on iPhone sales remains a concern for investors, even as its services segment shows continued growth.

title: With robotaxis still a distant dream, lidar makes itself useful
summary: The article discusses how lidar technology, initially poised for robotaxis, is now finding more immediate applications in advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) for passenger cars due to delays in fully autonomous vehicles. Companies specializing in lidar are pivoting to make the sensors more affordable for semi-autonomous features, with the market for lidar sensors in light-duty vehicles projected to reach $46 billion by 2030. Despite skepticism from some, lidar is increasingly seen as a critical safety component for higher levels of autonomy, offering a more robust alternative or complement to camera and radar systems.

title: Geojit Financial Services launches AI-powered global investment platform
summary: Geojit Financial Services has launched an AI-powered global investment platform in partnership with Stockal, a New York-based wealth management services platform. This new platform allows Indian investors to diversify their portfolios by investing in global equities, starting with US stocks and ETFs. The initiative aims to cater to the growing interest among domestic investors, high-net-worth individuals, and expatriates in global asset classes.

title: Amazon bites into Apple's share of Jabil's revenues
summary: Amazon has significantly increased its business with St. Petersburg-based Jabil in 2020, becoming a larger customer. While Apple remains Jabil's biggest revenue source, Amazon's share of Jabil's revenues grew substantially this year. This indicates a diversification of Jabil's customer base.

title: Apple shrinks, Amazon grows among Jabil’s largest customers
summary: Jabil's annual report shows a shift in its largest customer base, with Apple's share of revenue decreasing while Amazon's grows significantly. This diversification strategy aims to reduce Jabil's reliance on a single customer, a concern previously highlighted by analysts. The company also reported an increase in employees and manufacturing space, along with COVID-19 related costs.

title: Election, Stimulus, or Rising Infections — What’s Driving Market Volatility?
summary: The ProShares Ultra VIX Short-Term Futures ETF (UVXY) spiked significantly on October 26th due to increased stock market volatility. This surge was attributed to concerns over rising COVID-19 infections, stalled stimulus talks, and upcoming U.S. elections and mega-cap company earnings reports. The article explains how the VIX Index and UVXY function in measuring and leveraging market volatility.

title: Apple, Google and a Deal That Controls the Internet (Published 2020)
summary: The Justice Department has filed a landmark antitrust lawsuit against Google, targeting a secretive partnership with Apple worth billions where Google's search engine is the preselected choice on Apple devices. This alliance, seen as "co-opetition" by former Apple counsel, is now under scrutiny for potentially stifling competition and preventing smaller companies from flourishing. The lawsuit highlights the complex relationship between the two tech giants and their role in controlling web search.

title: How to invest in the S&P 500 without betting hard on the ‘FAAMG’ stocks that are 20% of the index
summary: This article discusses a strategy for investing in the S&P 500 without being overly reliant on the performance of the dominant "FAAMG" stocks. It highlights that the FAAMG stocks (Facebook, Apple, Amazon.com, Microsoft, and Google/Alphabet) collectively represent about 20% of the S&P 500's valuation. The piece suggests that investing in an equal-weight S&P 500 ETF can mitigate the concentrated risk associated with these technology giants.

title: How to invest in the S&P 500 without betting hard on the ‘FAAMG’ stocks that are 20% of the index
summary: This article discusses how to invest in the S&P 500 without heavily relying on the "FAAMG" stocks (Facebook, Apple, Amazon.com, Microsoft, and Google/Alphabet), which represent a significant portion of the index's valuation. It suggests that when investing in a standard S&P 500 index fund, one is implicitly making a large bet on the continued success of these five tech giants. The article hints at an alternative strategy, specifically mentioning an "Equal-weight S&P 500 ETF," for investors looking to diversify away from the concentrated influence of FAAMG stocks within the S&P 500.

title: How to invest in the S&P 500 without betting hard on the ‘FAAMG’ stocks that are 20% of the index
summary: This article discusses a strategy to invest in the S&P 500 without being overly exposed to the "FAAMG" stocks (Facebook, Apple, Amazon.com, Microsoft, and Google/Alphabet) which collectively represent 20% of the index's valuation. It suggests that when investing in a typical S&P 500 index fund, one is inherently making a significant bet on the continued success of these five dominant companies. The piece broadly hints at an "equal-weight S&P 500 ETF" as a potential solution for investors seeking diversification away from these outsized positions.

title: AT&T Has The Most Disappointing Big Company Stock This Year
summary: AT&T Inc. (NYSE: T) has recorded the worst stock performance among large-cap companies this year, dropping 27% while the S&P 500 gained 7%. This decline is significant compared to top companies like Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Alphabet, and Facebook, which have seen substantial gains. The company also reported a 5% fall in operating revenue and a 22% drop in EPS, coupled with massive long-term debt, despite an impressive dividend yield.

title: ExxonMobil Deploys QR Codes And NFC Tags for Streamlined Mobile Payment at the Pump
summary: ExxonMobil is implementing QR codes and NFC tags at over 11,500 U.S. stations to enable streamlined mobile payments with Apple Pay and Google Pay. This system leverages Apple App Clips for iPhone users without the ExxonMobil app and provides a web-based solution for Android users, enhancing contactless payment options at the pump. The initiative is part of ExxonMobil's ongoing efforts to innovate and offer secure, convenient payment methods, building on prior contactless payment solutions like "Alexa, Pay for Gas."

title: If you suddenly can't print to your HP Printer from your Mac, you're not alone: Code security cert snafu blamed
summary: Many Mac users are unable to print to their HP printers due to a code-signing certificate issue affecting macOS Catalina and Mojave. Apple, via an XProtect update, revoked the certificate for HP's printer driver software, causing Macs to reject it as potentially damaging. HP later confirmed they "unintentionally revoked credentials on some older versions of Mac drivers" and are working with Apple to restore them, recommending AirPrint as a temporary workaround.

title: Apple, Google Worked as ‘One Company’ on Search Deal, U.S. Says
summary: The U.S. Justice Department has filed an antitrust lawsuit against Alphabet Inc.'s Google, accusing it of abusing its monopoly in search through a multibillion-dollar deal with Apple Inc. This agreement makes Google the default search engine on iPhones and other Apple devices. Documents from Google reportedly describe the potential loss of this deal as a "Code Red."

title: South Korea's SK Hynix to buy Intel's NAND business for $9 bln
summary: SK Hynix is set to acquire Intel's NAND memory chip business for $9 billion in an all-cash deal, positioning the South Korean company as the world's second-largest NAND memory producer. This move allows Intel to divest its non-core businesses and focus on its more lucrative Optane memory technology, while SK Hynix aims to boost its NAND capacity and market share. The deal is expected to consolidate the memory chip industry, despite initial negative reaction from SK Hynix shareholders regarding the price.

title: Fisker closes deal for supplier Magna to build its SUV, take stake in startup
summary: Fisker Inc. announced a deal with Magna International Inc. for Magna to supply the vehicle platform and build its Ocean SUV, with Magna also receiving warrants for up to a 6% stake in Fisker. This partnership marks Magna's first entry into contract manufacturing for an EV startup and is seen as critical for Fisker's future, targeting significant sales volumes for the Ocean SUV starting in 2022. Fisker's merger with Spartan Energy Acquisition Corp. is expected to close on Oct. 30, with shares trading as "FSR" on the NYSE.

title: Free Apple 5G iPhones are offered by carriers to lure upgraders
summary: US carriers such as AT&T and Verizon are offering free Apple iPhone 12 devices to new and existing customers to attract subscribers during the 5G upgrade cycle. These promotions require qualifying trade-ins and unlimited plans. The carriers are gambling that by covering the phone cost, subscribers will sign up for higher-priced unlimited data plans, despite potential economic headwinds and initial limited 5G network speeds.

title: Buy HomePod mini
summary: This page on Apple's website facilitates the purchase of the HomePod mini, detailing its features and comparing it to the larger HomePod. It highlights the HomePod mini's surprising sound, smart home capabilities, and includes information about a free Apple Music trial. The page also provides extensive details regarding AppleCare One and AppleCare+ plans, outlining their terms, conditions, and coverage for various devices, including accidental damage, theft, and loss.

title: Apple introduces iPhone 12 Pro and iPhone 12 Pro Max with 5G
summary: Apple announced the iPhone 12 Pro and iPhone 12 Pro Max, featuring 5G capability, the A14 Bionic chip, a new design with Ceramic Shield, and advanced pro camera systems. These new iPhones also introduce a LiDAR Scanner for AR and MagSafe for enhanced wireless charging and accessories. Pre-orders for the iPhone 12 Pro begin October 16, and for the iPhone 12 Pro Max on November 6.

title: Corning Inc. glass technology used for new iPhone 12
summary: Corning Inc.'s new Ceramic Shield technology is being utilized in Apple’s newly unveiled iPhone 12, significantly improving its durability. This advanced glass-ceramic material, developed in collaboration with Apple, offers 4X better drop performance than previous iPhone models. Apple invested $250 million from its Advanced Manufacturing Fund into Corning Inc. to support research and development for next-generation consumer devices.

title: 'The next generation is here': Apple unveils its first-ever 5G iPhone
summary: Apple officially unveiled its first-ever 5G iPhone, the iPhone 12, marking a "new era" for the company. CEO Tim Cook highlighted the significance of the 5G technology, which industry analysts regard as a "once-in-a-decade product cycle." The new line includes the iPhone 12 Mini, iPhone 12, iPhone 12 Pro, and iPhone 12 Pro Max, with varying features and price points, and also introduced a revamped HomePod mini.

title: Peloton rolling out "Skip Intro" feature
summary: Peloton is introducing a "Skip Intro" feature for experienced riders, allowing them to bypass the minute-long class introductions. This feature will be available on Peloton hardware and the web, but not on their apps, and requires users to have completed at least five cycling classes to unlock it. The update aims to improve the workout experience for those already familiar with Peloton's interface and class structure.

title: U.S. judge rules Apple could bar Epic Games's 'Fortnite' from App Store
summary: A federal judge ruled that Apple Inc. could remove Epic Games's "Fortnite" from its App Store but must not impact Epic's developer tools business, which includes the "Unreal Engine" software. This decision partially granted and partially denied Epic Games' preliminary injunction request in their lawsuit against Apple regarding anticompetitive behavior concerning App Store commissions and controls. The judge acknowledged Epic's strong arguments but stated Epic had not sufficiently addressed Apple's counterarguments.

title: Flexjet, Sentient Jet boss sets SPAC to target $100 million + acquistions
summary: Kenn Ricci, the principal of Directional Aviation (which controls Flexjet and Sentient Jet), is launching Zanite Acquisition Corporation (ZAC), a Special Purpose Acquisition Company. ZAC aims to target next-generation aviation acquisitions valued above Directional Aviation's typical $150 million ceiling, focusing on new areas like electric and sustainable aviation. This move addresses a gap between Directional Aviation's usual investment range and the larger investments pursued by private equity firms.

title: Morgan Stanley’s Makeover (Published 2020)
summary: Morgan Stanley is continuing its strategic shift away from investment banking toward steadier, fee-based businesses, exemplified by its recent $7 billion acquisition of Eaton Vance. This move, coupled with the earlier E-Trade purchase, aims to bolster its wealth and investment management divisions, which already account for over half of its revenue. CEO James Gorman hopes this transformation will lead analysts to value Morgan Stanley more like Charles Schwab, which trades at a higher earnings multiple.

title: QQQ’s Stellar ETF Rise
summary: The article discusses the enduring success of the Invesco QQQ Trust (QQQ) ETF despite criticisms of its underlying Nasdaq-100 index structure. It highlights QQQ's significant asset growth, strong performance against major indices, and its appeal to investors seeking exposure to tech and growth stocks, particularly among younger generations. The piece also delves into the unique rules and rebalancing methodology of the Nasdaq-100 and QQQ's substantial marketing efforts.

title: Walmart tests electronic tech services similar to Best Buy's Geek Squad
summary: Walmart is testing electronic tech services, similar to Best Buy's Geek Squad, in partnership with True Network Solutions. The services are being piloted in a Springdale, Arkansas Supercenter and four Dallas-Fort Worth area stores, offering smartphone repairs and diagnostic data recovery among other tech support. This initiative positions Walmart to compete with Best Buy by offering lower prices on services like screen replacements.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | General Motors’ Credit Card, Brought to You by Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs is set to acquire General Motors' credit-card business for approximately $2.5 billion, marking its second co-branded credit card venture after the Apple card. This deal expands Goldman's presence in Main Street lending, giving it ownership of over a million GM cardholders and their $8.5 billion in annual spending. The acquisition takes place during a challenging economic period when banks are bracing for potential losses due to deferred payments linked to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: All of 'Mad Men' Available on AMC Plus
summary: All seven seasons of the AMC hit drama "Mad Men" are now available commercial-free on AMC Plus, AMC Networks’ new streaming bundle. The streaming service also features original programming from AMC, IFC, BBC America, WE TV, and SundanceTV, including shows like "The Walking Dead" and "Killing Eve." AMC Plus is accessible to subscribers of Amazon Prime Video Channels, Apple TV Channels, Comcast Xfinity, Dish, and Sling TV, with pricing set at $8.99 monthly for some providers.

title: Mediaweek Roundup: Simon Reeve, Netflix, Dean Jones, ABC + more
summary: This Mediaweek Roundup covers several key media industry stories, including a coalition of smaller app companies forming to challenge Apple and Google's app store policies, former Seven Network presenter Simon Reeve suing the network for over $500,000, and a call for Netflix to contribute more to Australian content production. It also touches on celebrity manager Sam Mangan's "virtual" LA office, Peter V'landys suing ABC, and the passing of cricket legend Dean Jones.

title: 3 quick reasons I like the IOO ETF
summary: The iShares Global 100 ETF (ASX: IOO) is recommended for its three key features: diversification from the Australian market, exposure to global developed and emerging markets, and investment in strong, growing businesses with entrenched economic moats. The article highlights its holdings in major global companies like Apple and Microsoft, and its 10-year average annual return of 13.1%. The author suggests it's a good option for investors seeking to diversify beyond ASX shares.

title: To Fight Apple and Google, Smaller App Rivals Organize a Coalition (Published 2020)
summary: Smaller app developers like Spotify, Match Group, and Epic Games have formed the "Coalition for App Fairness" to challenge the dominance and app store practices of Apple and Google. This move comes as scrutiny intensifies on major tech companies for alleged antitrust violations. The coalition aims to advocate for changes in app store policies and "protect the app economy."

title: Spotify, Match Launch Coalition to Protest App Store Rules
summary: Spotify, Match Group, Epic Games, and 10 other organizations have formed the Coalition for App Fairness to challenge the app store rules of Apple and Google. The coalition introduced "App Store Principles," advocating against platform owners using developer data to compete and requiring exclusive use of their app stores or payment systems. This move aims to pressure Apple and Google into modifying their existing app store guidelines.

title: Honest Company Founder Jessica Alba: Ethics shouldn’t be a ‘marketing ploy’
summary: Jessica Alba, founder of The Honest Company, states that ethics should be an inherent part of a company's model rather than just a marketing ploy, and that businesses can achieve both social good and profitability. She highlights how The Honest Company's commitment to ethical practices and transparency gives it a competitive advantage, despite past challenges. The company has seen significant growth, partly due to new disinfectant products during the pandemic, and aims to continue positively influencing how other companies operate.

title: Is the VGS ETF the best for passive investing?
summary: This article examines the Vanguard MSCI Index International Shares ETF (ASX: VGS) as a strong option for passive investing due to its broad diversification across over 1,500 businesses in major developed countries. It highlights VGS's sector allocation, top holdings including tech giants, and its average annual return of 9.65% over the past five years. The piece concludes that while VGS offers good diversification, investors should consider its management fee compared to other ETFs and explore various options for growth and dividends.

title: Prepear Stands Up To Apple
summary: Prepear, a small Provo-based food prep startup, is fighting Apple's formal opposition to its trademark, which Apple claims could cause consumer confusion due to a stylized apple and pear logo. Prepear's CEO views Apple's actions as bullying and an injustice, especially against a company helping small food bloggers secure sustainable revenue. Over 260,000 people have signed a Change.org petition supporting Prepear, and the two parties are currently in negotiations for a settlement.

title: Peacock Now Available on the Roku Platform
summary: Peacock announced its app is now available nationwide on the Roku® platform, reaching an estimated 100 million people. This partnership expands Peacock's reach and provides Roku users with access to over 20,000 hours of on-demand movies, shows, live news, and sports programming, including a free tier offering 13,000 hours of premium content. Both companies expressed excitement about delivering high-quality content to engaged streamers.

title: Expedia Group Unveils New Widgets and App Clip for iOS 14
summary: Expedia Group has released new versions of its Brand Expedia, Hotwire, and Vrbo iOS apps, integrating new features available in iOS 14. These updates include widgets for easier access to travel details and deals, an App Clip for Hotwire, and improved transparency and planning tools aimed at simplifying travel bookings and experiences. The enhancements are designed to provide users with more information at a glance and help them access discounts for last-minute accommodations.

title: Trump Blesses Oracle’s TikTok Deal, Delaying Potential U.S. Ban
authors: Jennifer Jacobs and Shelly Banjo / Bloomberg
summary: President Trump approved Oracle Corp.'s bid for TikTok's American operations, delaying a potential U.S. ban on the video-sharing app. The deal involves the creation of TikTok Global, with Oracle taking a 12.5% stake and Walmart Inc. taking 7.5%, and includes a $5 billion contribution to a U.S. education fund as well as the creation of 25,000 jobs. This agreement aims to address U.S. national security concerns while allowing TikTok to continue operating in the country.

title: Oracle (ORCL) Trading Lower After TikTok Download Ban
summary: Oracle (ORCL) stock is trading lower after the U.S. Commerce Department banned TikTok and WeChat downloads, effective Sunday. The announcement creates uncertainty around Oracle's potential deal for TikTok's U.S. operations, with the stock needing to hold the $57 to $57.50 price zone to maintain a bullish technical outlook. Long-term patterns suggest only modest upside even if a deal is finalized, and a failed deal could trigger a bearish double top pattern.

title: IBM Remains America’s Worst Big Tech Company
summary: Despite a change in CEO, IBM continues to underperform significantly compared to other major tech companies, with its stock price declining while competitors surge. The company has experienced nearly six years of revenue decline and its cloud operations show minimal growth, placing it outside the top 50 American companies by market capitalization. IBM lacks strong consumer-focused products and its key brands like Watson and The Weather Channel fail to provide compelling growth engines, indicating a dim future for its return to the top tier of tech.

title: Anthem Announces Research Study with Apple Watch to Help Improve Asthma Management
summary: Anthem, Inc. announced a new two-year research study in collaboration with Apple, Inc. and University of California, Irvine, to investigate how Apple Watch and iPhone can help individuals self-manage asthma and improve clinical outcomes. The study will enroll participants from Anthem-affiliated health plans and explore the use of digital tools and data from everyday devices to predict asthma exacerbation and serve as potential digital biomarkers. Participants will receive an Apple Watch and Beddit™ Sleep Monitor, and the active group will have access to a digital asthma tool for symptom tracking, personalized nudges, and educational resources.

title: Stock ETFs Gain Amid Positive Economic Data And Tech Rebound
summary: Stock index ETFs and individual stocks rallied on Tuesday, September 15, 2020, driven by a rebound in tech stocks, positive economic data from China and the U.S., and optimism surrounding coronavirus vaccine trials. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all advanced, with tech giants like Apple, Microsoft, Netflix, and Facebook leading the gains, while the banking sector lagged. Analysts have also raised the year-end target for the S&P 500 due to tech mergers and sector excitement.

title: What to Expect with the Release of Apple iOS14
summary: Apple's iOS14 update introduces significant privacy changes, requiring consumer opt-in for sharing personal data with third-party apps for ad targeting, primarily affecting the use of the IDFA. This shift presents challenges for app advertisers and platforms like Outbrain, which are adapting by participating in Apple’s SKAdNetwork framework, working with Mobile Measurement Partners, and leveraging their extensive network on the open web. The changes are expected to have a massive impact on in-app advertising, particularly for social platforms like Facebook, making it crucial for advertisers to diversify their media mix.

title: The 6 Most Interesting Things Apple Just Announced
summary: Apple unveiled several new products and services, including two new Apple Watches, a fitness subscription service called Fitness+, and updates to its iPad lineup. The company also introduced Apple One, a bundled subscription service for its various offerings, aiming to simplify subscriptions for users. Notable product improvements include a blood oxygen sensor in the Apple Watch Series 6 and a faster processor for the entry-level iPad and iPad Air.

title: Why Investors Should Not Expect a NextEra Stock Split to Act Like Apple or Tesla
summary: NextEra Energy Inc. announced a 4-for-1 stock split and increased its financial expectations for 2021, 2022, and 2023. While stock splits often generate excitement, investors are cautioned not to expect a similar stock surge seen with Apple and Tesla, as NextEra is a utility stock with different market dynamics. Despite being the largest U.S. utility by market cap and a strong performer, its P/E ratios and low dividend yield reflect a different investment profile.

title: Here is everything that was announced at today’s Apple event
authors: Kevin Parrish and Christian de Looper
summary: Apple held its annual hardware event on September 15, 2020, announcing several new products and services, though notably without a new iPhone. Key revelations included the Apple Watch Series 6, a budget-friendly Apple Watch SE, updated iPad Air and entry-level iPad models, and the new Apple One subscription service. The company also unveiled Apple Fitness+ and confirmed the release of iOS 14 and other software updates on September 16.

title: Apple event: A new fitness service and updates to Watch and iPad
summary: Apple announced a new remote fitness service called Fitness+ along with updated versions of its Apple Watch and iPad products. The Fitness+ service, available at $9.99 a month, will offer online workout videos and integrate with the Apple Watch and music service. The new Apple Watch Series 6 will include blood oxygen measurement and an improved sleep tracker, while Apple also introduced a new service bundle called Apple One, starting at $14.95 a month.

title: Why Nvidia is spending $40 billion on Arm
summary: Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm, if completed, would be the largest semiconductor deal ever and is primarily aimed at boosting Nvidia's data center business by integrating Arm's CPU technology with Nvidia's GPUs. The deal raises questions about Nvidia's ability to neutrally license Arm's technology to competitors like Apple and Samsung, but Nvidia plans to operate Arm as an independent, customer-neutral subsidiary. Investors reacted positively to the news, and Nvidia sees significant potential in infusing its AI and graphics chips into Arm's vast ecosystem.

title: ARM: Can 'crown jewel' of UK technology be protected?
summary: The UK government is considering options to protect Cambridge-based ARM Holdings after its acquisition by Nvidia, a move that contrasts with their earlier stance during Softbank's purchase in 2016. ARM's co-founder has criticized the deal, fearing Nvidia will disrupt ARM's business model. While Nvidia promises UK investment, blocking the deal poses challenges given current laws and potential impacts on foreign investment.

title: -Nvidia to buy chip designer Arm for $40 bln as SoftBank exits
summary: Nvidia announced its acquisition of UK-based chip designer Arm from SoftBank Group for $40 billion, a deal set to significantly impact the global semiconductor sector. The acquisition poses questions regarding Arm's maintained neutrality under U.S. ownership and faces regulatory scrutiny, particularly in China. Nvidia plans to expand Arm's licensing model and integrate its own IP, while SoftBank exits Arm to raise cash.

title: Nvidia jumps on $40 billion chip deal; analysts expect tough scrutiny
summary: Nvidia's shares surged after announcing a $40 billion deal to acquire UK-based chip designer Arm from SoftBank, marking a potential shift in the chip industry landscape. Analysts anticipate significant regulatory challenges for the acquisition, particularly from China, due to its scale and implications for competition. The deal is seen as a major move for Nvidia, positioning it among top chip suppliers, but also raising concerns among rivals and regulators.

title: Apple’s First Major Product Launch Event of 2020: What to Watch
summary: Apple Inc. is set to unveil new products at a virtual event, including upgrades to its Apple Watch and iPad Air. The new Apple Watch Series 6 is expected to feature a faster processor and a blood oxygen meter, alongside a new low-end model. While headphones and a smaller HomePod are also anticipated, new iPhones will be introduced at a later date.

title: Ninth Circuit’s Ruling In Frlekin v. Apple, Inc. Is A Cautionary Tale For Employers
summary: The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in Frlekin v. Apple, Inc. that Apple must compensate California non-exempt employees for time spent waiting for and submitting to mandatory bag searches. This decision, influenced by a California Supreme Court ruling emphasizing employer control, highlights the need for employers to compensate employees for all time under their control and consider using arbitration agreements with class action waivers to mitigate exposure.

title: Precedential Opinion: Board weighs six factors in discretionary denial analysis
summary: The Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB) has issued a precedential opinion outlining six factors it considers when deciding whether to discretionarily deny an IPR petition due to parallel litigation. These factors aim to address efficiency concerns and potential conflicts with ongoing district court proceedings, particularly when a trial date is set before the Board's final written decision. The guidance provides clarity for parties on arguments related to discretionary denials based on the stage of related litigation.

title: Using Foreign Funds to Correct for a Sliding Dollar
summary: The dollar has recently been in decline relative to other foreign currencies, primarily due to low interest rates and a shift in the Fed's monetary policy. This can have varying implications for investors' portfolios depending on their holdings. Foreign stock and bond funds, particularly unhedged ones, can benefit from a weaker dollar, while U.S. companies with significant foreign revenue may also see improved profits.

title: Apple Marina Bay Sands opens Thursday in Singapore
summary: Apple is opening its new Apple Marina Bay Sands store in Singapore on Thursday, September 10, the first Apple Store to sit directly on the water. The unique spherical, all-glass dome structure offers 360-degree panoramic views and will feature "Today at Apple" sessions and an underwater boardroom. The store continues Apple's 40-year commitment to Singapore and will implement rigorous health measures for visitors.

title: Apple’s ‘dark side’ led these brothers to launch the AppRising
summary: Ben and Dan Volach, Israeli brothers who deeply admire Apple products, are leading an "AppRising" against Apple Inc. and its App Store. They view Apple as a monopoly and have filed antitrust litigation, preceding similar actions by other companies like Epic Games.

title: -Broadcom signals delay in iPhone chip ramp-up, pointing to later release date
summary: Broadcom, a key Apple supplier, indicated a delay in its annual chip shipments, suggesting the next iPhone launch will be later than usual. This comes after Broadcom previously warned of lower revenues due to a delayed phone launch from its "large North American mobile phone customer," believed to be Apple. Analysts widely expect Apple's new 5G-enabled iPhone to launch in October due to coronavirus-related disruptions.

title: Publishers are getting a (brief) reprieve from Apple’s coming ad-pocalypse
summary: Apple has delayed a planned privacy change for iOS 14, requiring explicit user permission for ad tracking, until early 2021. This move provides a temporary reprieve for publishers and developers who rely on ad revenue, giving them more time to adapt. While larger publishers like The New York Times are better equipped to handle these changes with their own data stacks, smaller entities will face greater challenges and may resort to tighter registration walls.

title: Apple delays iPhone change that's expected to make it harder for Facebook and other apps to target ads
summary: Apple announced a delay until early 2021 for a planned change to the iPhone operating system that would impact how mobile advertisers track users. This privacy-focused update, previously set for iOS 14, gives developers more time to adapt to new rules requiring user permission to track their activity. The change is expected to significantly affect mobile advertising, with Facebook warning of potential revenue drops for publishers.

title: The 2020 Edition Zepp E Smartwatch Is Tested By Luxurious Magazine
summary: Luxurious Magazine reviewed the 2020 Zepp E smartwatch, highlighting its style, ease of use, and comprehensive features. The Zepp E, priced from £209, comes in Circle and Square variants and is compatible with both iOS and Android systems. The article praises its design, 5ATM water resistance, and various health tracking and sports modes accessible via its intuitive interface and dedicated app.

title: What Enabled Adobe to Raise Its Digital Media ARR?
summary: Adobe's Digital Media ARR increased due to the continued migration of its Creative Suite and the addition of new Creative Cloud subscriptions. The company saw significant growth in its Digital Media segment, with Creative Cloud revenues rising 44% year-over-year, leading Adobe to raise its fiscal 2016 Digital Media ARR guidance to $4.0 billion. Fiscal 1Q16 was the last quarter Adobe provided specific Creative Cloud subscriber figures.

title: Apple and Tesla shares spike after stock splits kick in
summary: Apple and Tesla shares surged on Monday after their stock splits took effect, attracting significant investor buying. Apple jumped over 4 percent after its 4-for-1 split, while Tesla rallied 10 percent following its 5-for-1 split, elevating its market capitalization to over $440 billion and showcasing the impact of increased affordability for individual investors. The success of these splits may encourage other companies with high-priced stocks to consider similar moves, as both Silicon Valley companies have strong individual investor followings.

title: Three things you need to know about Apple’s stock split
summary: Apple Inc. underwent a four-for-one stock split after the close of trading on Friday, August 28, 2020. This is the fifth split in the company's history and aims to make shares more accessible to a broader base of investors. As a result, Apple's component weighting in the price-weighted Dow Jones Industrial Average will decrease significantly.

title: Insulin Pump Market Heats Up Among Rivals Medtronic, Insulet and Tandem
summary: The insulin pump market is experiencing increased competition among key players Medtronic, Insulet, and Tandem. This article highlights the intensifying rivalry and recent activities of these companies, including partnerships and technological advancements. It suggests a dynamic landscape in the diabetic care medical device sector.

title: Investor, Philanthropist Warren Buffett Turns 90
summary: The article celebrates Warren Buffett's 90th birthday, highlighting his career as a renowned investor and philanthropist. It delves into his early life, his journey to becoming CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, and his investment philosophy which emphasizes value investing, patience, and emotional control. The piece also acknowledges his substantial philanthropic contributions and shares several of his famous quotes on investing and life.

title: Apple v. Prepear : Does Apple Really Need All the Fruit?
summary: This article discusses the trademark dispute between Apple Inc. and Prepear, a small meal prep app company, over Prepear's pear-shaped logo. Apple filed an opposition with the USPTO, claiming likelihood of consumer confusion and brand dilution, sparking debate on whether Apple is protecting its brand or engaging in trademark bullying. The author questions Apple's argument that food and meal planning services are within its natural "zone of expansion."

title: Apple says Fortnite maker wanted ‘Epic Games Store’ in App Store
summary: Apple has alleged that Epic Games' CEO sought a "side letter" to establish its own game store within the App Store, which Apple viewed as a move to undermine its commission-based model. This claim was made in a court filing as Apple sought to block Epic's request to remain in the App Store amidst their dispute over in-app payment rules. Apple categorized Fortnite's removal as a "self-inflicted wound" by Epic, stating that Epic knowingly breached their agreement.

title: Apple is valued at $2 trillion as investor confidence grows
summary: Apple Inc. reached a market valuation of over $2 trillion in August 2020, just two years after hitting $1 trillion. This surge is attributed to growing investor confidence in Apple's shift toward services and surprisingly strong quarterly results despite the pandemic, with its stock up 57% year-to-date at the time. The company's market capitalization now rivals the combined value of the S&P 500's 200 smallest companies.

title: Intel rolls out $10B stock buyback, CEO says stock is cheap
summary: Intel announced a new $10 billion stock buyback program through accelerated share repurchase agreements, with the CEO stating the stock is trading below its intrinsic valuation. This move is part of a larger $20 billion buyback plan initiated in October, which was suspended in March. The company will fund these repurchases using existing cash resources.

title: Apple Becomes First U.S. Company Worth More Than $2 Trillion
summary: Apple achieved a new financial milestone, becoming the first publicly traded U.S. company to reach a market capitalization of over $2 trillion. This valuation marks a doubling in just two years, driven by a strong stock performance, especially during the pandemic due to work-from-home trends and robust online sales. The company's market cap now surpasses that of other U.S. tech giants and the GDP of several developed countries, with a four-for-one stock split planned to make shares more accessible.

title: Apple's $2 trillion value is proof that Tim Cook's services plan worked
summary: Apple reached a $2 trillion valuation, largely symbolic but indicative of CEO Tim Cook's successful pivot towards a services-led business model. Investors are increasingly valuing Apple like a software company, reflected in its rising P-E ratio, as the company diversified its revenue streams beyond hardware. This shift helped Apple double its value in just over two years, despite challenges like App Store criticism and dependence on its existing device base.

title: Apple becomes US' first $2T company
summary: Apple Inc. has become the first U.S. company to achieve a $2 trillion market capitalization, with its share price climbing above $467.77. This milestone follows its previous achievement of being the first U.S. company to reach a $1 trillion market cap just over two years prior. The tech giant's market cap soared by 59% this year, joining Saudi Aramco as the only other company globally to reach this valuation.

title: Apple Inc. (AAPL) tops $2 trillion market capitalization
summary: Apple Inc. (AAPL) reached a market capitalization of over $2 trillion in intraday trading, marking a significant milestone for the tech giant. This achievement follows a strong rally in tech stocks amidst the pandemic, with Apple's stock more than doubling since March 2020. The article discusses Apple's valuation, its recent 4-for-1 stock split, and the broader market implications of such high valuations.

title: The Inside Story Of Robinhood’s Billionaire Founders, Option Kid Cowboys And The Wall Street Sharks That Feed On Them
summary: This article delves into Robinhood's rapid rise, driven by commission-free trading and a surge of novice investors during the pandemic, and reveals its controversial business model of selling customer order flow to high-frequency trading firms. It explores how this model, while minting billionaire founders, prioritizes profit from sophisticated market makers, potentially at the expense of inexperienced traders. The piece also highlights the platform's challenges, including outages and the tragic death of a user, leading to calls for better regulation and education.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Launches hum by Colgate: The New Smart Electric Toothbrush that Guides Users to Brush Better and Get In Sync with Their Smile
summary: Colgate-Palmolive has launched hum by Colgate, a new smart electric toothbrush designed to help users improve their brushing habits. The toothbrush features smart sensors that track brushing frequency, duration, and coverage, providing personalized guidance and helping users achieve 50% better brushing efficacy. The accompanying app offers rewards through "Smile points" and integrates with the Apple Health app for a holistic wellness experience.

title: Small Headphone Specialist Koss Corp. Attempts to Slay Giants Apple, Bose & Others in Court
summary: Koss Corporation has initiated significant litigation against major industry brands including Apple and Bose, alleging infringement on its wireless headphone and speaker patents. This move comes after Koss successfully recovered funds from a previous embezzlement scandal, suggesting a new focus on intellectual property enforcement following a failed "Striva" product line due to economic realities and market challenges. Apple has responded with a countersuit, claiming Koss violated a confidentiality agreement, which could impact the jurisdiction of the cases.

title: Investing in Nasdaq 100 in 2000
summary: This article analyzes the long-term performance of investing in the Nasdaq 100 in 2000, a period of extremely high valuations. The author conducts an in-depth study showing that while the index as a whole tripled in value by 2020, this was driven by a small number of winning companies, particularly Apple and Amazon, and required significant patience through a prolonged drawdown. The study extracts key lessons for investors, including the importance of diversification, patience, holding onto winners, and understanding that valuation ultimately matters.

title: Tesla to Enact 5-for-1 Stock Split
summary: Tesla Inc. announced a 5-for-1 stock split following a significant surge in its share price, which has made it the most valuable car company. This move comes after four consecutive quarters of profit and expectations of its first-ever full-year profit. Tesla's shares increased by over 6% in after-hours trading after the announcement.

title: In Victory for Qualcomm, Appeals Court Throws Out Antitrust Ruling (Published 2020)
summary: A federal appeals court overturned a 2019 antitrust ruling against Qualcomm, validating its business model and patent licensing practices. The three-judge panel reversed a decision that found Qualcomm abused its monopoly position in wireless chips and overcharged mobile phone makers. This ruling, along with a recent licensing deal with Huawei, is seen as a significant boost for Qualcomm's business, with its shares rising over 2 percent.

title: [Interview] Manga platform Piccoma ready to take over Japan's comics market
summary: Piccoma, a manga platform by Kakao Japan, is rapidly expanding in Japan's digital comics market, becoming the top-grossing non-gaming app in July. Despite a late start, Piccoma's focus on Korean webtoons has driven significant revenue growth, making it a frontrunner in the world's largest comics market. The company plans to enhance content quality, user experience through big data and AI, and is preparing for an IPO to fund its continued growth and market dominance.
source: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition
source_domain: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition

title: Apple Countersues Stereo Headphone Inventor Koss Over Patent Lawsuit
summary: Apple has countersued stereo headphone inventor and manufacturer Koss over a patent lawsuit accusing Apple and other companies of violating patents related to wireless headphone technology. Apple claims Koss's allegations are baseless and that the lawsuit breaks a confidentiality agreement from 2017. Apple also submitted evidence to refute Koss's claims of patent infringement.

title: Apple’s Employee Uniforms Tied to Forced Labor in Xinjiang
summary: A Tech Transparency Project (TTP) investigation reveals that Apple's employee uniforms are sourced from Esquel Group, a company sanctioned by the U.S. government in July 2020 for its involvement in forced labor and human rights abuses in China’s Xinjiang region. This finding undermines Apple's claims of having "zero tolerance" for forced labor in its supply chain. Despite Apple's denial of direct sourcing from Esquel, shipping records and industry reports suggest a long-standing relationship and reliance on Xinjiang cotton, highlighting Apple's entanglement with problematic labor practices in China.

title: Get Long Alibaba Stock Into Earnings With Confidence
summary: This article suggests investors consider going long on Alibaba (BABA) stock, despite market volatility and potential risks like U.S.-China rhetoric. It highlights BABA's strong recovery post-quarantine and its status as a superstar stock, comparable to other tech giants. The author recommends using options strategies, specifically selling puts, to enter positions with managed risk ahead of earnings.

title: Ford CEO Jim Hackett to retire; Chief Operating Officer Jim Farley will take helm
summary: Ford Motor Co. CEO Jim Hackett is retiring from his position, effective October 1, 2020, and will be succeeded by Chief Operating Officer Jim Farley. Hackett led the company since May 2017, overseeing a restructuring plan and challenges with product launches and stock value, while Farley is known as a "car guy" with a strong background in the auto industry and a focus on flawless product execution and an expanded affordable lineup. The transition comes as Ford faces intense competition and an evolving industry landscape, with many analysts and employees expressing optimism about Farley's leadership.

title: Disney Quarterly Earnings: Parks Lose $2 Billion, WDW Attendance Down & More
summary: The Walt Disney Company reported its Q3 2020 earnings, revealing significant losses, especially for the Parks, Resorts & Experiences division, which lost $2 billion. Despite a revenue decrease of 42% year-over-year, Disney's stock saw an after-hours bump, and Disney+ exceeded revised subscriber expectations, reaching 60.5 million. The company is weathering the financial storm with $23 billion in cash and is adapting to challenges, including lower-than-expected Walt Disney World attendance, by optimizing operations despite reduced CapEx and potential long-term recovery in destination travel.

title: Apple iPhone Revenue by Year: FY 2007 – 2020
