summary: This article presents Apple iPhone revenue data from fiscal year 2007 to 2020, highlighting a significant 14.6% year-over-year decline in fiscal 2019 revenue to $142,381 million due to decreased iPhone sales. It also provides background information on Apple Inc., its founding, key product launches including the first iPhone, and its valuation as one of the world's most valuable brands.

title: Oprah Winfrey names “Caste: The Origins of Our Discontents” her most important Book Club selection ever
summary: Oprah Winfrey has chosen Isabel Wilkerson's "Caste: The Origins of Our Discontents" as her most important Book Club selection to date. The book, available on Apple Books, explores America's hierarchical structure and will be accompanied by an exclusive excerpt narrated by Winfrey and a discussion with Wilkerson on Apple TV+. Winfrey will also serve as Apple News's first-ever guest editor, curating related content.

title: Ford Motor Company gets new CEO on October 1st
summary: Jim Hackett is retiring as CEO of Ford Motor Company after three years, with current Chief Operating Officer Jim Farley taking over on October 1st, 2020. Farley aims for a 10% operating margin and acknowledges new competitors like Amazon, Baidu, Tesla, and Apple. He also faces the challenge of reviving Ford's declining car sales in China and navigating the company through the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

title: Who Is on Apple’s Board, and Why
summary: This article details the composition of Apple's board of directors, highlighting its relatively small size and stability. It introduces each board member, including Tim Cook, Art Levinson, Al Gore, Andrea Jung, Ron Sugar, Sue Wagner, and James Bell, outlining their backgrounds, key contributions, and the rationale behind their selection. The piece also touches on their compensation and significant stock holdings.

title: Apple Cost of Sales by Year: FY 1990 - 2020
summary: This article presents Apple's cost of sales data from fiscal year 1990 to 2020, highlighting an annual decline of 1.2% in 2019 to $161,782 million, following an all-time high of $163,756 million in FY'18. It also provides a brief overview of Apple Inc.'s history, including its founding, key products like the iPhone, and its market valuation.

title: Tim Cook Says These 3 Words Guide Every Decision at Apple
summary: Tim Cook stated that "privacy, security, and quality" guide every decision at Apple, especially in its app review process. The article argues that these three words differentiate Apple from its competitors, particularly concerning data privacy and product experience. It emphasizes that these principles provide clarity for Apple's decisions and are foundational to its operations, serving as a lesson for other leaders.

title: Chinese artificial intelligence company files $1.4 billion lawsuit against Apple
summary: Chinese artificial intelligence company Xiao-i has filed a lawsuit against Apple Inc., seeking 10 billion yuan ($1.43 billion) in damages. Xiao-i alleges that Apple's Siri voice-recognition technology infringes on a patent it secured in 2009. This lawsuit is a continuation of a nearly decade-long dispute between the two companies over patent infringement.

title: Apple Announces 4-1 Stock Split After Shares Surge Toward $400
summary: Apple Inc. announced a 4-for-1 stock split following a significant surge in its share price over the past year. The company stated this move aims to make the stock more accessible to a broader base of investors, with post-split trading beginning on August 31. This marks Apple's fifth stock split since going public in 1980, contrasting with other large tech companies that typically avoid such actions.

title: PayPal Plots a POS Course With QR Codes As It Comes Off the ‘Strongest’ Quarter in Its History
summary: PayPal is significantly expanding its physical point-of-sale strategy by rolling out QR code payment acceptance, starting with a major deal with CVS Pharmacy to service all 8,000 stores by year-end. This move comes as the company reports its "strongest" quarter in history, driven by increased active accounts, payment volume, and revenue during the coronavirus pandemic. PayPal is also working with over 100 enterprise merchants in the U.S. and Europe to further integrate QR code payments, highlighting their strategic importance for daily use and future economic benefits.

title: Here’s what the CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Alphabet will say at Wednesday’s antitrust hearing
summary: The CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Alphabet are scheduled to testify before a House antitrust panel on Wednesday. Their prepared statements indicate they will argue that competition exists and their companies strengthen America. The executives, including Jeff Bezos, Tim Cook, Mark Zuckerberg, and Sundar Pichai, will appear via videoconference.

title: Prudential and PAI Health enter partnership to deliver the new way to measure physical activity on digital health app, Pulse
summary: Prudential Corporation Asia and PAI Health have partnered to integrate PAI Health's Personal Activity Intelligence (PAI) score into Prudential's Pulse digital health app across 11 Asian markets. This collaboration aims to enhance customer engagement by providing a science-backed metric to measure physical activity and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease mortality. Pulse users, with a compatible heart monitor wearable, will benefit from personalized guidance on physical activity, with the potential to extend lives.

title: Boyd Gaming unveils mobile gaming app with nostalgic brand
summary: Boyd Gaming Corp. has launched a new mobile gaming app called Stardust Social Casino, leveraging its vintage Las Vegas Stardust brand to stand out in the competitive mobile gaming market. The app offers virtual versions of slot titles found on Boyd Gaming casino floors, primarily for entertainment, and allows members of its B Connected loyalty program to earn points for in-app purchases. This move aims to connect with existing customers and attract new players familiar with the historic Stardust brand.

title: Charting a bull-trend pullback, S&P 500 ventures under the breakout point
summary: The S&P 500 has pulled back below its breakout point of 3,233, extending to deeper support around the 3,200 mark, amidst heightened China-U.S. diplomatic tensions. The early Friday session low of 3,202 matched this inflection point, making the weekly close significant for further insight. This occurs while the NASDAQ 100 is challenging trendline support and Apple has violated a key trendline, though the article advises against panic.

title: Abbott receives FDA approval for neurostimulator-controlling iPhone app for personalizing therapies for pain, Parkinson's disease
summary: Abbott has received FDA approval for its new NeuroSphere Digital Care platform and patient controller app, allowing users to personalize neuromodulation therapies for chronic pain and movement disorders like Parkinson's disease via their iPhones. The app aims to enhance remote patient engagement and virtual connections with healthcare providers, eliminating the need for a separate programmer device. This approval builds on Abbott's existing neuromodulation devices and platforms, reflecting a shift towards digital health solutions during the pandemic.

title: Intel's 7nm is Broken, Company Announces Delay Until 2022, 2023
summary: Intel announced a significant delay in the rollout of its 7nm CPUs, pushing their debut to late 2022 or early 2023. This delay is attributed to a "defect mode" causing yield degradation, putting Intel approximately twelve months behind its internal targets for 7nm process. The company is now exploring contingency plans, including the use of third-party foundries for some components and entire chip designs, and plans to increase shipments of 10nm chips by 20%.

title: Koss Sues Apple, Bose, Over Wireless Headphone Patents (2)
summary: Koss Corp. has filed a series of lawsuits in Texas federal court, alleging that Apple Inc., Bose Corp., Plantronics Inc., Skullcandy Inc., and JLab Audio infringe on its wireless headphone patents. The patents cover technology that Koss claims it pioneered, including internal microphones, touch controls, and Wi-Fi connectivity in headphones. These lawsuits assert that the widespread adoption of such features in modern wireless headphones infringes on Koss's early innovations.

title: Tesla deal could make US blacklisted Israeli billionaire richer
authors: Franz Wild and Michael Kavanagh and Bloomberg
summary: Tesla's agreement to buy cobalt from Glencore could indirectly benefit Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler, who has been blacklisted from the US financial system since 2017. Gertler is entitled to royalties from Glencore's Congolese mines, which will supply most of Tesla's cobalt, raising ethical and potential legal concerns for the US company. This arrangement highlights the complexities of sourcing minerals from regions with human rights issues and corruption risks.

title: Qualcomm Quarterly Revenue by Segment
summary: The article analyzes Qualcomm's quarterly revenue by segment from Q1 2005 to Q2 2020, highlighting that the QCT semiconductor business accounted for 78.6% of total revenue in fiscal Q2 2020. It details the performance of Qualcomm's QCT, QTL, and QSI segments, noting a significant decline in QSI due to an impairment loss related to OneWeb's bankruptcy. The report explains the factors driving segment-specific revenue changes.

title: Work From Home ETF Already Impressing
summary: The Direxion Work From Home ETF (WFH) has quickly gained over $50 million in assets and shown strong performance since its launch. The fund invests in companies across four technology pillars related to remote work and is seen as a credible long-term investment. WFH's underlying index has a higher price-to-sales multiple than the S&P 500 but a discount to the Nasdaq-100, with strong forecasted earnings growth.

title: Jamf's stock soars in its public debut, after IPO prices above expectations
summary: Jamf Holding Corp.'s stock made a strong public debut, with shares opening 77% above its initial public offering price of $26, which was higher than expected. The company sold 18 million shares, raising $468 million, and was valued at $3.03 billion at the IPO price. This successful market entry occurred during a period of significant rallies for IPOs and the broader S&P 500.

title: Apple teams up with HBCUs to bring coding and creativity opportunities to communities across the US
summary: Apple is expanding its Community Education Initiative by partnering with an additional 10 Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). These partnerships will create regional coding centers that serve as technology hubs for campuses and their broader communities, offering opportunities in coding, creativity, and workforce development. This effort aims to advance educational equity and increase the representation of Black students and women in STEM and technology fields.

title: Charles Schwab says retail trading kept booming in second quarter amid market comeback
summary: Charles Schwab reported a significant surge in retail trading activity and new accounts in the second quarter of 2020, with 1.62 million daily active trades and 1.6 million new accounts added, including 1.1 million from the USAA acquisition. Despite this growth, the company missed analyst estimates for both revenue and earnings per share, primarily due to a decline in net interest revenue. Schwab also made "significant progress" on its pending acquisition of TD Ameritrade.

title: COVID-19 Impact & Recovery Analysis- Beacon Market
summary: Technavio predicts the beacon market will grow by $15.99 billion between 2020 and 2024, with a CAGR of nearly 57%, despite the impact of COVID-19. Key players include Apple Inc., Google LLC, and Texas Instruments Inc. The growth is primarily attributed to the increasing adoption of premium smartphones in emerging economies, though data security concerns pose a challenge.

title: Apple CEO Tim Cook No.2 on 2019 highest paid list at $133.7 million
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook ranked second on the 2019 highest-paid executive list with $133.7 million, largely due to an equity grant he received in 2011. Elon Musk topped the list with $595.3 million, primarily from a pay deal tied to Tesla's valuation. The article highlights the significant compensation packages in the tech industry compared to other sectors like finance.

title: Smart investment during a pandemic
summary: Franklin Templeton advocates for a well-diversified global investment portfolio to navigate market uncertainties during a pandemic. They suggest adopting "Defend, Diversify, and Buffer" strategies to protect investments and seize opportunities in sectors like technology and emerging markets. The article emphasizes long-term trends and the benefits of professional fund management over market timing.

title: Walmart Just Made a Bold Move That Families Are Going to Love. It's a Lesson in Emotional Intelligence
summary: Walmart launched two initiatives, "Camp by Walmart" and "Walmart Drive-In," to provide safe entertainment for families during the Covid-19 pandemic. These moves demonstrate emotional intelligence by addressing a key customer need and strengthening relationships with budget-conscious families. The article suggests that businesses of all sizes can learn from Walmart's approach by identifying and filling customer needs to build stronger brand connections.

title: Santander appoints three leading technologists to support its strategy and digital transformation
summary: Santander has appointed R. Martin Chávez, Sebastian Gunningham, and Francisco D’Souza to key roles to bolster its digital transformation. Chávez will join the board as an independent director, Gunningham will chair Santander Consumer Finance and become vice chairman of Openbank, and D’Souza will be a strategic advisor for Santander Global Platform. These appointments aim to leverage their extensive technology and financial sector experience to drive Santander's digital strategy.

title: Software Maker for Apple Devices Jamf Files for U.S. IPO
Apple to Drop Intel and Use its own Chips in Mac Computers
summary: Apple announced its decision to transition from using Intel-based chips to its own Apple Silicon chips for its Mac computers, with the first Macs featuring these new chips expected by late 2020. This move aims to enhance Mac performance, efficiency, and establish a common architecture across all Apple products, allowing Mac computers to run apps previously exclusive to iPhones and iPads. The new Apple chips are based on technology from Arm Holdings, whose technology also powers the world's fastest supercomputer, Fugaku.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Apple buys Fleetsmith, a company making it easier to deploy iPhones and Macs at workplaces
summary: Apple has acquired Fleetsmith, a company specializing in tools for deploying and managing corporate iPhones and Macs. This acquisition aims to strengthen Apple's offerings in the enterprise market, a sector Apple CEO Tim Cook previously called the "mother of all opportunities." Fleetsmith's mobile device management software helps businesses remotely configure and manage Apple devices for their workforce.

title: Apple, Google and chorus of tech business leaders slam Trump's new visa restrictions
summary: Tech giants Apple and Google, along with other prominent business leaders, criticized the Trump administration's new restrictions on work visas, including the H-1B and L-1 visas. Critics argue that these restrictions, implemented to free up jobs for American workers, will actually hinder job creation and economic growth. CEOs like Tim Cook, Sundar Pichai, Brad Smith, Marc Benioff, and Elon Musk all expressed disappointment, highlighting the positive contributions of immigrant workers to innovation and the U.S. economy.

title: Trump signs order freezing visas for foreign workers through the end of the year
summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order freezing new visas for various foreign workers, including tech and low-skill jobs, through the end of 2020. This action, aiming to preserve jobs amidst the COVID-19 economic downturn, exempts specific essential workers but includes au pairs and certain other exchange programs. The policy is expected to face backlash from the business community and immigration advocates despite the White House's claim of saving or creating 525,000 American jobs.

title: After 15 Years, Apple Prepares to Break Up With Intel (Published 2020)
summary: Apple is preparing to end its 15-year partnership with Intel, with plans to replace Intel processors in Macs with self-designed chips. This move, expected to be announced soon, signifies Apple's growing independence and determination to control its product manufacturing, a trend seen among other major tech companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Google. The new Mac chips are anticipated to arrive next year and will likely be manufactured by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

title: Apple, ARM, and Intel
summary: This article discusses Apple's anticipated transition of its Mac computers from Intel processors to its own ARM-based chips, highlighting the historical context of this decision, Intel's manufacturing struggles, and the potential implications for performance and the broader server market. It also critically examines Intel's past strategic missteps, particularly its decision regarding iPhone chip production.

title: Intel Loses a Chip Wizard at the Worst Possible Time
summary: Intel's top chip architect, Jim Keller, resigned effective immediately for personal reasons after only two years with the company. This departure is seen as a significant blow to Intel, which is already ceding ground to rivals in a competitive market, and comes at a challenging time for the chip giant. Keller's extensive experience from companies like Apple and AMD highlights the severity of his exit for Intel.

title: Former Apple executive Jim Keller resigns from top chip design role at Intel
summary: Jim Keller, a prominent chip designer known for his work at Apple, Tesla, and AMD, has resigned from his role at Intel for personal reasons. His departure raises concerns among analysts about Intel's processor roadmap and vulnerability to competition, especially with Apple reportedly planning to use its own chips in Macs. Keller will serve as a consultant for Intel for six months during the transition.

title: Intel loses ‘rock star’ chip designer Jim Keller
summary: Intel Corp. has announced the departure of its celebrated chip designer, Jim Keller, who is leaving for "personal reasons" after two years with the company. Keller, known for his work at AMD, Apple, and Tesla, was instrumental in Intel's efforts to expand beyond traditional PC and server chips into new markets like AI and cloud computing. Despite his departure, Intel has already reorganized its engineering leadership and Keller will serve as a consultant for six months to ensure a smooth transition.

title: Apple begins to sell Sonos as the speaker company accuses Google and Amazon of patent theft
summary: Apple has started selling the Sonos One SL Wireless Speaker online and in its stores. This comes as Sonos has publicly sued Google and accused Amazon of patent theft related to its streaming technology. The Sonos One SL speaker can stream Apple Music via Siri or AirPlay 2.

title: San Jose-based Cisco promises $5M for charities fighting racism, discrimination
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. announced it would donate $5 million to charities combating racism and discrimination, following widespread protests over racial injustice. Other tech companies like Facebook, Intel, and Apple have also pledged similar contributions. This decision led Cisco to postpone its annual Cisco Live event, with CEO Chuck Robbins emphasizing the need for space and healing amid current societal turmoil.

title: This Rugged Safari-Style Defender Is Resto-Modding Done Right
summary: ECD Automotive Design has transformed a Land Rover Defender 90 into a rugged safari-style vehicle, combining luxury and utility. This resto-mod features a Chevy LS3 V8 engine, upgraded Fox suspension, Nappa leather interior, and a Coniston Green paint job, making it ideal for summer adventures.

title: Roberto Escobar, former Medellín Cartel accountant, sues Apple for $2.6 billion, report says
summary: Roberto Escobar, brother of Pablo Escobar and former Medellín Cartel accountant, is suing Apple for $2.6 billion. He claims an iPhone security flaw exposed his address via FaceTime, leading to threats and relocation. This lawsuit coincides with Escobar's marketing efforts for his own line of gold-plated iPhones and a website criticizing Apple.

title: Same Old Leadership Song Lifts These Leveraged ETFs
summary: Technology sector leadership is driving the stock market's recovery from March lows, benefiting leveraged ETFs like Direxion Daily Technology Bull 3X Shares (NYSE: TECL) and Direxion Daily Dow Jones Internet Bull 3X Shares (NYSE: WEBL). TECL is a triple-leveraged play on Microsoft and Apple, while WEBL offers a similar leveraged exposure to internet giants like Amazon, Facebook, and Netflix. Both ETFs have seen significant gains and investor interest due to the strong performance of their underlying tech and internet components.

title: Fingerprint Sensor Market to Grow with 13.6% CAGR in Coming Years: P&S Intelligence
summary: The global fingerprint sensors market is projected to grow at a 13.6% CAGR between 2020 and 2030, driven by increasing security concerns and the rising integration of fingerprint-sensing technology in smartphones and other consumer electronics. Area/touch sensors, particularly those based on capacitive technology, are expected to experience the fastest demand growth. Asia-Pacific is forecasted to be the region with the highest CAGR, propelled by government initiatives and the booming population's adoption of smart devices.

title: Revised Apple campus site plan in Northwest Austin includes new 6-story hotel
summary: Apple Inc.'s revised site plan for its new Northwest Austin campus now includes a 6-story hotel featuring 192 rooms. The new campus, approved by the city on April 29, is located on a 133-acre tract and is expected to house up to 15,000 workers, with the first buildings projected to open in 2022. This expansion also highlights Apple's continued manufacturing presence in Northwest Austin, where Mac Pro computers are produced.

title: Apple checks in with 192-room hotel for billion-dollar Northwest Austin campus
summary: Apple updated its plans for its new $1 billion corporate campus in Northwest Austin to include a 192-room hotel. This addition is seen as a trendsetting move by corporate location consultant John Boyd Jr., who expects more companies to integrate hotels into their campuses, particularly after the COVID-19 pandemic, to enhance control over corporate travel and ensure traveler security. The campus, set to open in 2022, will eventually house up to 15,000 employees and will be Apple's largest hub outside its Cupertino headquarters.

title: Why Intel is betting its chips on microprocessor mastermind Jim Keller
summary: This article profiles Jim Keller, a legendary microprocessor designer who has worked for Apple, Tesla, and AMD, and is now tasked with revitalizing Intel's chip-design enterprise. It explores his unconventional career path, his philosophy of simplification and learning, and the significant impact his designs have had on the tech industry, including the Ryzen chips for AMD and the Autopilot chip for Tesla. The piece details how Intel is relying on Keller to overcome its recent struggles and regain its market leadership.

title: Premium Calm meditation app membership now included on American Express cards
summary: American Express has launched a new perk offering a complimentary one-year premium membership to the Calm meditation and sleep app for all its US personal card members, starting May 18. This membership, normally costing $69.99 annually, can be extended for a second year at 50% off with automatic renewal, and also applies to American Express corporate cards. This initiative aims to provide valuable well-being resources during stressful times and enhance the appeal of Amex's personal card lineup, although business cards are not eligible.

title: C.H. Robinson launches Navisphere on Apple, Andriod
summary: C.H. Robinson has launched its Navisphere platform on Apple and Android smartphones, significantly extending its global reach. This new app allows users to access detailed shipment information, track movements, view documents, and contact account representatives directly. The move reinforces C.H. Robinson's commitment to mobile technology, building on previous mobile app developments for carriers.

title: An insight into procurement at Apple Inc.
summary: This article explores Apple Inc.'s procurement strategies, highlighting its rigorous supplier standards and commitment to a diverse supplier base. It details how Apple requires its suppliers to align with its culture, innovation values, and social responsibilities. The piece also outlines the process for becoming an Apple supplier and the initiatives of its Supplier Diversity Programme, established in 1993.

title: Apple Credit Card: five facts to know ahead of the US August launch
summary: Apple Inc. has partnered with Mastercard Inc. and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. to launch the Apple Card in the U.S. in August, aiming to reimagine the classic credit card with a focus on simplicity, transparency, and privacy. Key features include enhanced financial control, integration with Apple Wallet for spending insights, real-time finance management, and cash-back rewards. The card also boasts advanced cybersecurity solutions and privacy protections, including specific measures to prevent fraudulent activity and ensure user data is not sold to third parties.

title: U.S. moves to cut Huawei off from global chip suppliers as China eyes retaliation
summary: The Trump administration moved to block global chip supplies to Huawei Technologies, expanding U.S. authority to require licenses for semiconductors made abroad with U.S. technology. This action has sparked fears of Chinese retaliation, with reports suggesting Beijing is ready to target U.S. companies like Apple, Cisco, Qualcomm, and Boeing. The new rule impacts major contract chipmakers like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) and raises concerns for the global semiconductor supply chain while aiming to protect 5G network integrity.

title: TSMC, maker of iPhone chips, to build $12bn chip factory in US
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), a major supplier to Apple Inc., announced plans to build a $12 billion chip factory in Arizona, in partnership with the US government. This move aligns with the Trump administration's efforts to increase foreign manufacturing in the US and will create up to 1,600 jobs, producing advanced 5-nanometer chips. The investment highlights the strategic importance of semiconductor production within the US amidst growing US-China trade tensions.

title: TSMC’s Announcement Of A New U.S. Semiconductor Fab Is Big News
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) announced plans to build a new semiconductor fabrication facility (fab) in Arizona, a move deemed significant despite its initial limited scale. This investment, estimated at $12 billion for a 5 nm technology fab, highlights the challenges and costs of advanced semiconductor manufacturing. While a welcome development for the U.S. supply chain, it represents only a small step towards securing domestic semiconductor production, as the U.S. will still rely heavily on Asian facilities for capacity and specialized processes like packaging.

title: Kevin O'Leary: If you're worried about dividend cuts, it's 'time to use actively managed ETFs'
summary: Kevin O'Leary suggests that actively managed ETFs are a valuable tool for investors concerned about dividend cuts and market volatility, particularly in an uncertain market environment. He highlights O'Shares FTSE U.S. Quality Dividend ETF (OUSA) as an example of an actively managed fund that focuses on companies with high-quality balance sheets and lower likelihood of cutting dividends. O'Leary emphasizes that in these times, quality really matters and active management can help cherry-pick sound investments.

title: Halliburton lays off 1,000 employees from corporate headquarters in Houston
authors: Stan Choe (Damian J. Troise and Alex Viega - AP Business Writers)
summary: Halliburton announced it is laying off approximately 1,000 employees from its Houston corporate headquarters due to the dramatic business downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic and an unprecedented commodity price decline. This comes after the company closed two other Texas facilities, with some employees relocated. The article also provides a stock market update indicating a general market dip despite tech stock gains and reports on severe job losses.

title: Cancer drug firm’s Hong Kong IPO is oversubscribed 639 times
summary: Akesobio, a Chinese cancer drug firm, experienced a highly successful IPO in Hong Kong, with its US$330 million offering being oversubscribed 639 times by local investors. This makes it Hong Kong's largest IPO this year and the most popular biotechnology listing by funds frozen, attracting HK$166.5 billion in investor funds. Analysts note the difficulty in discerning whether the popularity is driven by short-term speculation or genuine belief in the drug development pipeline.

title: Apple and Google partner on COVID-19 contact tracing technology
summary: Apple and Google are collaborating on a joint effort to enable the use of Bluetooth technology for COVID-19 contact tracing, prioritizing user privacy and security. The solution will be rolled out in two phases, starting with APIs in May and then integrating functionality directly into underlying operating systems. This initiative aims to help governments and health authorities reduce the spread of the virus.

title: Lawsuits accuse United, Cigna of underpaying for behavioral health claims
summary: Four class-action lawsuits have been filed against United Behavioral Health and Cigna Behavioral Health, accusing them of underpaying providers for mental health services. The lawsuits allege that the insurers used a third-party vendor, Viant, to negotiate dramatically reduced reimbursements, leading to significant balance bills for patients and breach of contract for providers. Patients and providers are seeking justice in federal courts, claiming that regulators have ignored their complaints about these unethical practices.

title: PepsiCo commits more than $45M to coronavirus food, PPE initiatives
summary: PepsiCo announced a global initiative committing over $45 million to support communities affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The funding will provide protective gear for healthcare workers, testing services, and distribute more than 50 million nutritious meals worldwide. This effort is part of a broader corporate response to the ongoing crisis, leveraging PepsiCo's resources to aid the most vulnerable.

title: 3M CEO vows coronavirus expansion of critical N95 mask production
summary: 3M CEO Mike Roman announced a significant expansion of critical N95 mask production to support healthcare workers during the coronavirus pandemic. The company has already doubled its U.S. mask production to 35 million respirators a month and plans to double it again within the year. Roman noted that 3M began preparing for a pandemic after the 2002 SARS epidemic and ramped up production in January ahead of the current crisis, with FDA approval now allowing industrial N95 masks for healthcare use.

title: 2019 Annual Report
summary: Goldman Sachs' 2019 Annual Report details the firm's financial performance of $36.55 billion in net revenues and a 10.0% return on average common shareholders’ equity, alongside a strategic outlook for growth and increased efficiency. The report highlights the firm's commitment to core values, diversity, and sustainability, while acknowledging the profound impact and uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 pandemic on the global economy. David M. Solomon emphasizes the firm's resilience, client focus, and ongoing efforts to strengthen existing businesses and invest in new opportunities.

title: Two per head: Apple caps iPhone sales as supply chains break
summary: Apple Inc. is limiting customer purchases of iPhones to two per person as it struggles with production amidst the coronavirus pandemic and supply chain disruptions. This move comes after the company closed its brick-and-mortar stores outside China and faces weakening demand globally, despite Chinese factories resuming operations. The purchase limits may also aim to prevent scalpers from stockpiling and reselling devices.

title: Introducing Logitech Combo Touch Case With iPad
summary: Logitech announced the Combo Touch, a new keyboard case with an integrated trackpad for the iPad (7th generation), iPad Air (3rd generation), and iPad Pro (10.5-inch). This accessory combines Logitech's best-selling iPad keyboard, featuring Smart Connector compatibility, with a precision trackpad for enhanced productivity and navigation. The Combo Touch offers multiple use modes, backlit keys, and protection for the iPad, with availability expected in May 2020 for $149.99.

title: A Tribute to Amory Houghton
summary: This article is a tribute to former Congressman Amory Houghton Jr. (R-NY), who passed away at age 93. It highlights his career as CEO of Corning Glass Works and his nine terms in Congress, emphasizing his role as an exemplary moderate Republican rooted in the company and community of Corning, New York. The piece details his moderate political views, fiscal conservatism, belief in science and long-term thinking, and efforts to bridge political divides, contrasting him with the increasingly polarized political landscape, even as he remained optimistic about a moderate Republican revival.

title: How Supply Chain Disruptions Are Accelerating Robotics Adoption
summary: The article discusses how recent global events like trade conflicts and the COVID-19 pandemic are pushing companies to reconsider their offshoring strategies and prioritize supply chain integrity. It argues that reshoring manufacturing, despite higher labor costs in developed economies, will be accelerated by the increasing adoption of robotics and automation technologies, which help offset expenses and improve efficiency. The author highlights the growing investment in robotics, falling costs, and improving capabilities as key drivers for this paradigm shift.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch Is The Latest Retailer To Close Stores Due To Coronavirus
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch announced the closure of all its stores in North America and Europe, including Hollister branded stores, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company will continue online sales and pay store associates, while also withdrawing its financial outlook for the first quarter and annual period. This decision follows similar closures by other major retailers like Nike and Apple.

title: Broadcom withdraws 2020 revenue forecast on coronavirus worries
summary: Broadcom Inc. has withdrawn its revenue forecast for 2020 due to demand and supply disruptions caused by the coronavirus outbreak, joining other chipmakers in revising their outlooks. Despite a slowdown in demand, the company stated its supply chain was not meaningfully impacted. Broadcom expects second-quarter revenue of approximately $5.7 billion, lower than analysts' average estimates.

title: Zero-Day Bug In Verisign And IaaS Services Allowed Registering of Malicious Domains With Homoglyph
summary: A zero-day bug found in Verisign and various IaaS services allowed cybercriminals to register malicious domains using homoglyphs, making them appear visually identical to legitimate sites. A researcher exposed the flaw, which had been actively exploited since 2017, and successfully registered imposter domains for major companies. While Verisign and Amazon have implemented mitigations, other services have yet to address the vulnerability.
source: Latest Hacking News - Exploits, Vulnerabilities, Tech and Tutorials
source_domain: Latest Hacking News - Exploits, Vulnerabilities, Tech and Tutorials

title: Coronavirus drags iPhone shipments to China down 60 percent
summary: Apple's iPhone shipments in China plummeted over 60% in February due to the coronavirus outbreak, which forced store closures and hampered manufacturing. This decline, representing about 494,600 units, significantly impacted overall mobile phone shipments in China. While analysts believe the decline reflects postponed purchases, a prolonged outbreak could affect the launch of Apple's 5G iPhones and has already led to concerns about the company's Q2 China sales.

title: Technology trumps consumer staples in the hunt for quality
summary: This article argues that the traditional strength of consumer staples has waned, while the technology sector now offers superior investment opportunities, particularly when viewed through a "franchise power/growth framework." It highlights the shift in leadership from consumer staples to IT, attributing technology's rise to strong business franchises, network effects, and a move towards subscription-based software models. The author also compares the portfolio weightings and performance of various quality investment funds, showing a trend towards higher tech exposure.

title: Lawmakers ask Amazon, EBay to crack down on counterfeit sales
summary: House lawmakers are urging Amazon.com Inc. and EBay Inc. to take stronger action against third-party vendors selling fake, stolen, or unsafe goods on their platforms. The bipartisan request follows concerns about organized retail crime and counterfeit products, especially those originating from China. Both Amazon and EBay executives testified that they are investing in tools and supporting law enforcement to combat fraudulent listings.

title: Apple Supplier Cuts Down Revenue, EPS Guidance Due To Coronavirus – States Manufacturing Operations Remain Unaffected
summary: Apple supplier Skyworks Solutions, Inc (NASDAQ:SWKS) has revised its revenue and EPS guidance downward for fiscal Q2 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak, following a similar move by Apple and other suppliers. The company now expects revenues of $760 million - $770 million, a drop of $40 million - $50 million, and non-GAAP EPS of $1.34. Despite the revised estimates, Skyworks states that its manufacturing operations have not experienced significant disruption.

title: How to access Alaska Airlines movies and TV shows on your own device
summary: Alaska Airlines now offers over 600 free movies and TV shows via its Alaska Beyond Entertainment™ system, accessible directly from passengers' devices using a browser. This guide details how to connect to the "Alaska_WiFi" or "gogoinflight" network, use the browser-based entertainment, and troubleshoot common issues. It also clarifies that internet purchase is not required to access the free content and addresses frequently asked questions about device compatibility and privacy settings.

title: Dow's point drop worst on record as stocks fall into correction
summary: U.S. equity markets plunged into correction territory on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average experiencing its worst single point drop ever, falling over 1,193 points. The sell-off was fueled by growing concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, leading to significant losses across the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite, and impacting various sectors including technology, airlines, and oil. The market volatility occurred after President Trump announced a coronavirus task force and new cases of the virus were reported globally.

title: Why Apple and Johnson & Johnson's new heart study is a big deal for digital health
summary: Apple and Johnson & Johnson are partnering on a large-scale study to determine if the Apple Watch can detect atrial fibrillation in seniors, making it one of the largest randomized digital health trials ever. The study involves a unique collaboration between a tech company, a pharma giant, and a retailer (Best Buy), aiming to provide subsidized Apple Watches to 150,000 participants and address cardiologists' concerns about broad-based screening by focusing on a high-risk demographic. If successful, the initiative could lead to private Medicare plans covering Apple Watches and advance the concept of "aging in place" through digital health solutions.

title: Supreme Court rejects appeal in Apple’s $1-billion dispute over FaceTime patents
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court has rejected Apple's appeal in its decadelong patent dispute with VirnetX Holding Corp. over FaceTime technology. This decision means Apple may have to pay up to $1 billion in damages to VirnetX for using its secure communications technology without permission. VirnetX, a Nevada company with modest revenue, saw its stock jump significantly on the news.

title: Beyond ESG: How Individuals Can Influence Corporations
summary: This article discusses how individuals can influence corporations beyond traditional ESG investing by leveraging their consumer choices, employment decisions, and advocacy. It highlights the rise of stakeholder capitalism and provides examples of how customers, employees, suppliers, communities, and shareholders have successfully pressured companies to adopt more responsible practices, leading to positive corporate behavior and potentially superior stock returns.

title: This Growth ETF Continues Winning
summary: The article discusses the continued outperformance of growth stocks over value stocks in early 2020, driven by technology and consumer discretionary sectors. It highlights the SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 Growth ETF (SPYG) as a strong performer, noting its impressive year-to-date gains compared to the broader S&P 500 and S&P 500 Value Index. The piece also contrasts growth and value investing strategies and mentions significant inflows into SPYG.

title: HP Inc. PC President Alex Cho: ‘Get Ready For The Return Of The PC’
summary: HP Inc. PC President Alex Cho discusses the resurgence of the PC, particularly among Gen Z, debunking earlier predictions of its decline due to tablets. He highlights how HP is leaning into this trend by focusing on design, security, connectivity, and sustainability to meet the evolving needs of users who primarily use PCs for creation, consumption, and collaboration. The article anticipates future developments from HP, moving towards more empathetic computing experiences beyond traditional speeds and feeds.

title: Apple Unlikely to Meet Revenue Target Due to Coronavirus Impact
summary: Apple Inc. warned it is unlikely to meet its revenue target for the quarter ending in March due to the impact of the coronavirus outbreak, which has caused manufacturing slowdowns and weakened demand in China. The company's production facilities in China are ramping up slower than expected, leading to fewer iPhones available globally, and some retail stores remain closed or operate on reduced hours. Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives noted the impact is "worse than feared," though he remains optimistic about Apple's long-term recovery.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Oracle’s Larry Ellison makes friends with his enemy’s enemy, hosting a fundraiser for President Trump
summary: Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison is hosting a fundraiser for President Donald Trump, aligning with a shared adversary of Amazon and its CEO Jeff Bezos. Ellison's company has a fierce rivalry with Amazon's cloud computing wing, and Trump has openly expressed a desire to "screw Amazon." This move places Ellison among a few Silicon Valley figures who have publicly supported Trump, despite potential backlash from the tech industry.

title: iPhone 9 pre-order posters 'spotted' at Korea Telecom Retail stores
summary: Posters advertising pre-orders for the iPhone 9 have reportedly been spotted outside Korea Telecom retail stores in South Korea. The posters show a red iPhone alongside the Samsung Galaxy S20, hinting at an imminent release for both. While Apple has not officially announced the iPhone 9's launch, this leak suggests that Korea Telecom might be preparing for its arrival, potentially including a (Product)RED version.

title: Aramco IPO shows importance of timely index inclusion
summary: The article discusses the importance of timely index inclusion for large companies, using the Saudi Aramco IPO as a case study. It highlights how prompt inclusion can better reflect a country's economic drivers and improve index-to-economy alignment, especially for emerging markets. The author emphasizes that while regular reviews cover smaller securities, large IPOs may require off-cycle inclusion to accurately represent investment opportunities.

title: Goldman Sachs in talks with Amazon to offer small-business loans
summary: Goldman Sachs is reportedly close to a deal with Amazon to offer small-business loans to Amazon's U.S. customers, aiming to expand its reach onto Main Street. This move aligns with Goldman's strategy to diversify beyond trading and investment banking, while Amazon benefits by extending its lending platform without incurring significant credit risk or regulatory obligations. The partnership would leverage Goldman's financial services expertise and Amazon's vast network of small and medium-sized sellers, further solidifying both companies' ventures into new market segments.

title: Apple supplier Wistron to assemble key iPhone component in new India plant: sources
summary: Apple supplier Wistron Corp plans to assemble printed circuit boards (PCBs) for iPhones at its new plant in southern India, marking a significant expansion of Apple's manufacturing presence in the region. This move will help Apple save on import taxes on smartphone components, aligning with India's efforts to boost local manufacturing. The new facility, expected to be operational by April, will produce iPhone 7 and 8 models, with some intended for export, and has the capacity to produce up to 8 million smartphones annually.

title: A hidden stock tip in Apple earnings? Watch these semiconductor companies, analyst says
summary: Following Apple's remarkable sales rebound, an analyst suggests watching its semiconductor suppliers for investment opportunities. B. Riley analyst Craig Ellis highlighted Skyworks Solutions as a "buy," citing Apple CEO Tim Cook's report of "double-digit growth" in various markets. This indicates potential gains for semiconductor companies that supply Apple.

title: A hidden stock tip in Apple earnings? Watch these semiconductor companies, analyst says
summary: Following Apple's strong earnings report, an analyst suggests watching semiconductor companies, particularly Apple's critical suppliers. B. Riley analyst Craig Ellis highlighted Skyworks Solutions, rating it a "buy" with a price target indicating a potential 25% gain. This suggests that the positive momentum from Apple's sales rebound could extend to its chip suppliers.

title: A hidden stock tip in Apple earnings? Watch these semiconductor companies, analyst says
summary: Following Apple's strong earnings and stock performance, an analyst suggests watching its semiconductor suppliers. B. Riley analyst Craig Ellis highlighted Skyworks Solutions as a "buy" with a significant price target, indicating potential gains for the company and other major chip suppliers to Apple. This comes after Apple's CEO noted double-digit growth in various markets during their recent earnings call.

title: Qorvo Acquires UWB Chip Provider Decawave for $400m
summary: Qorvo has acquired Decawave, a UWB chip developer, for a reported $400 million. This acquisition is significant as it will advance the market penetration of IR-UWB technology, which offers highly precise location information and is gaining traction, especially with its integration into the iPhone 11 and its use in secure keyless entry systems for vehicles like Jaguar Land Rover. The move is expected to drive growth in the consumer, IoT, enterprise, and asset tracking markets by enabling new applications requiring accurate location capabilities.

title: The best apps to get fit with your friends: from Fitbit to Strava
summary: This article reviews popular fitness apps and devices like Strava, Fitbit, Garmin, and Apple Watch, highlighting their community features and suitability for different fitness goals. It aims to help users find the best platform to stay motivated and healthy with friends and family. The piece also mentions the free Couch to 5K app for beginners.

title: Tesla Exceeds Expectations in Blowout Quarter
summary: Tesla Inc. reported blowout earnings for the second consecutive quarter and accelerated the Model Y crossover's introduction, leading to a significant surge in its stock price. Despite skepticism and challenges like reduced capital expenditures and potential impacts from the coronavirus, analysts note a strong "sentiment shift" towards Tesla as a profitable and investable company. The company projects delivering at least 500,000 vehicles this year, a more than 35% jump from 2019, and does not plan to raise capital.

title: Apple, Broadcom Told to Pay Caltech $1.1B in Patent Lawsuit
summary: A federal jury has ordered Apple Inc. and Broadcom Inc. to pay $1.1 billion to the California Institute of Technology for infringing on Wi-Fi data transmission patents. The lawsuit focused on Broadcom's computer chips, which were used in various Apple devices including iPhones and iPads, with both companies' headquarters located in California. Caltech expressed satisfaction with the decision, while Apple and Broadcom did not immediately comment.

title: Apple travel to China could be cut after United reduces flights
summary: Apple Inc.'s ability to send engineers to China could be affected by United Airlines' decision to reduce flights there due to the rising coronavirus death toll. Apple, which designs products in Cupertino but manufactures mostly in China, reportedly buys around 50 business-class seats daily on the San Francisco to Shanghai route. The CDC has advised against non-essential travel to China, and Apple has already reduced store hours in some Chinese locations.

title: Which tech stock is best? Here’s how the ‘big five’ companies stack up as they report earnings
summary: MarketWatch discusses how the "big five" U.S. tech companies compare as they prepare to report earnings. Amazon is noted as an analyst favorite, while Apple is deemed the "cheapest" despite its recent stock run-up. The article previews the upcoming earnings reports, with Apple kicking off the round.

title: Which tech stock is best? Here’s how the ‘big five’ companies stack up as they report earnings
summary: This article examines how the "big five" U.S. tech companies are positioned as they prepare to report their quarterly earnings. It highlights Amazon as the favorite among analysts, while Apple is deemed the "cheapest" despite its recent stock performance. The article sets out to compare some of their key numbers ahead of Apple kicking off the earnings season.

title: The five biggest tech companies now make up 17.5% of the S&P 500 — here's how to protect yourself
summary: The five largest tech companies (Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, and Facebook) now comprise 17.5% of the S&P 500, leading to potential overexposure for passive investors. Financial advisors are suggesting strategies like equal-weighted funds, specialized tech ETFs focusing on emerging areas, and ESG investments to diversify portfolios. While Big Tech's dominance has driven strong returns, advisors emphasize balancing diversification with access to growth, cautioning against timing the market with large active bets.

title: Voting Gets Lazy; Cash-Craving Comcast; Broadcom Bites the Apple
summary: This article discusses several market topics, starting with the potential for smartphone voting and its implications for democracy. It then analyzes Comcast's strategy to offset video subscriber losses with price hikes and new streaming services, Intel's strong quarterly performance, and Broadcom's significant supply deal with Apple. Finally, it questions the market's enthusiastic reaction to American Express's latest earnings report and offers advice on navigating uncertain market conditions.

title: Broadcom touts $15B in Apple deals as it seeks buyer for one of its businesses
summary: Broadcom has announced $15 billion in deals to supply Apple with chips, while simultaneously seeking a buyer for its radio frequency chip business. Companies like Qorvo and Skyworks are potential candidates to acquire Broadcom's RF chip operations. This strategic move highlights Broadcom's significant partnership with Apple alongside its efforts to divest certain business units.

title: Apple, Broadcom Strike $15 Billion Worth of Chip-Supply Deals
summary: Broadcom Inc. has signed new multiyear agreements with Apple Inc. to supply high-performance wireless components and modules for Apple devices through mid-2023. These new pacts, combined with a similar agreement from 2019, are expected to generate approximately $15 billion in revenue for Broadcom. The chipmaker will supply these components for various Apple products.

title: Teardown: Apple iPhone 11 Pro Max
summary: This article provides a detailed teardown analysis of the Apple iPhone 11 Pro Max, highlighting its key specifications, manufacturing cost, and major internal components. It also touches upon Apple's strategy regarding 5G modems, including its settlement with Qualcomm and acquisition of Intel's modem business for future product development. The teardown provides insights into the device's camera modules, RF components, and main PC board.

title: Roku arrives in Brazil
summary: Roku, Inc. has announced its launch in Brazil, partnering with AOC to introduce AOC Roku TVs, making affordable streaming accessible to Brazilian consumers. The platform will feature a wide range of streaming channels, including local content through a partnership with Globoplay, providing users with a comprehensive entertainment experience. The 32-inch and 43-inch AOC Roku TV models will be available online and in stores starting January and February, respectively.

title: Apple eyes 11 Penn Plaza for new office space
summary: Apple is reportedly negotiating to lease approximately 200,000 square feet of office space at 11 Penn Plaza, a building owned by Vornado. This move comes after Apple lost a bid for space in the Farley Building to Facebook and is driven by the iPhone maker's current offices in the Flatiron District being at capacity. The deal could also help Macy's sublease part of its space in the building.

title: This Salesforce CEO Felt Stuck. Here Is the Business Advice Steve Jobs Gave Him That Changed Everything
summary: Marc Benioff, founder and co-CEO of Salesforce, credits Steve Jobs with invaluable advice that shaped his company. Jobs advised Benioff to make Salesforce 10 times larger within 24 months, close a major customer like Avon, and build an application economy, emphasizing the importance of being mindful and projecting the future. This guidance led Benioff to open up the Salesforce platform to developers, fostering innovation and contributing to his current net worth of $7.6 billion.

title: Now, Try Slicing the Stock Market Into Equal Pieces (Published 2020)
summary: This article explores an alternative approach to index fund investing: equal-weighted indexes, contrasting them with the more common capitalization-weighted indexes. It highlights that capitalization-weighted indexes, like the S&P 500, give more weight to larger companies, while equal-weighted funds allocate the same proportion to every company. The piece discusses the merits of both methods, noting that while equal-weighted funds can offer better diversification, capitalization-weighted funds have outperformed in recent years due to the continued rise of major companies.

title: Capitalism 'will fundamentally be in jeopardy' if business does not act on climate change, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella says
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella asserts that capitalism is in jeopardy if businesses fail to address climate change, emphasizing that corporations must find profitable solutions to planetary problems. Microsoft has committed to being carbon negative by 2030, investing $1 billion in carbon-removal technology, and CFO Amy Hood views these initiatives as "good return investments." This stance aligns with a growing trend of companies and investors prioritizing sustainability alongside financial performance.

title: Jabil: Diversified Manufacturer Growing with Technology
summary: Jabil Inc. is a leading diversified manufacturing services company with nearly $26.3 billion in revenue, specializing in automated, continuous flow manufacturing for major tech companies like Apple and HP. The company is broken into EMS and DMS segments and is growing rapidly in areas like 5G, IoT, and 3D printing. Jabil's diversified portfolio and strategic acquisitions, such as medical device manufacturing facilities from Johnson & Johnson, position it for continued growth despite risks related to its footprint in China.

title: The Mighty Apple, Google, Tesla, Dell and Microsoft in “the dock” - A Look At the Child Labour Lawsuit
summary: A landmark class-action lawsuit has been filed against Apple, Google, Tesla, Dell, and Microsoft, alleging their complicity in child labor practices within the cobalt mines of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The International Rights Advocates (IRA) are seeking injunctive relief and damages on behalf of child victims, arguing that these tech giants knowingly benefit from and aid in the exploitation of young children. The lawsuit highlights the horrific conditions faced by child miners and seeks comprehensive relief, including medical care, monitoring, and environmental cleanup, while asserting U.S. jurisdictional basis given the companies' operations and alleged willful ignorance.

title: American Tower not ruffled by Apple’s reported satellite efforts
summary: American Tower's CEO, Jim Taiclet, dismisses Apple's rumored satellite initiative, stating that direct satellite-to-device connectivity is unlikely to be economically scalable outside of niche, low-density scenarios. He asserts that macro towers remain the optimal technical solution for mobile architecture in most common environments. Taiclet also discussed American Tower's exploration of edge computing opportunities by leveraging its tower infrastructure for future storage and processing needs.

title: Insight Partners in Negotiation for a Stake in Gaming Company Moon Active
summary: Insight Partners is in advanced negotiations to acquire an 8%-10% stake in Israeli gaming company Moon Active Ltd. The deal is based on a company valuation of approximately $1.2 billion, with Insight Partners expected to pay between $100 million and $120 million to existing shareholders. Moon Active, known for its popular mobile game Coin Master, generates significant revenue, with key investors including Gigi Levy-Weiss.

title: The inside story of the ‘AppStore’, Salesforce’s Marc Benioff, and a gifted URL to Steve Jobs
summary: This article details how Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff came up with the "AppStore" concept and registered the domain AppStore.com years before Apple's App Store launched, following advice from Steve Jobs in 2003. Although Salesforce ultimately used "AppExchange" due to customer feedback, Benioff later gifted the AppStore.com domain to Steve Jobs when Apple unveiled its own App Store in 2008. The story highlights the shared foresight between the two tech leaders regarding a software ecosystem model.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | General Motors’ Credit Card, Brought to You by Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs is buying General Motors' credit-card business for approximately $2.5 billion, marking its second co-branded credit card venture after the Apple Card. This deal will give Goldman over a million new cardholders and their significant annual spending. The transaction is expected to finalize in the coming weeks, with Goldman aiming to cross-sell its own financial products to the new customer base.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | General Motors’ Credit Card, Brought to You by Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs is acquiring General Motors' credit card business for approximately $2.5 billion, marking a significant step in the investment bank's expansion into Main Street lending. This deal makes the GM card Goldman's second co-branded credit card, following its successful Apple Card launch. The acquisition will bring over a million GM cardholders and around $8.5 billion in annual spending to Goldman Sachs.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | General Motors’ Credit Card, Brought to You by Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs is acquiring General Motors' credit-card business for approximately $2.5 billion, marking its second co-branded credit card venture after the Apple card launch. This deal will transfer over a million GM cardholders and about $8.5 billion in annual spending to Goldman. The acquisition further solidifies Goldman's expansion into Main Street lending, even as it navigates economic uncertainties due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: After its strongest year in a decade, Apple stock is historically expensive on a price-to-earnings basis
summary: Apple's stock concluded its strongest year in a decade with its price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio reaching a historic high of 24.7, up from just over 13 at the beginning of 2019. This elevated P/E ratio makes Apple historically expensive compared to its past performance, although it remains below the average for the S&P 500 information technology index and many other megacap tech stocks. Factors like improved iPhone 11 expectations, anticipation of the 5G 2020 iPhone cycle, and strong wearable device performance have contributed to the increased valuation, according to Deutsche Bank analyst Jeriel Ong.

title: Here are the best and worst Dow and S&P 500 stocks of 2019
summary: The article highlights the best and worst performing stocks in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 for the year 2019. Apple led the Dow with an 86% return, while AMD was the top performer in the S&P 500. This strong market performance is attributed to the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts and foreign capital flowing into the U.S.

title: Here are the best-performing Nasdaq stocks of 2019
summary: This article highlights the top-performing Nasdaq stocks of 2019, following the Nasdaq Composite Index's rise past 9,000 points for the first time. AMD, Lam Research, and KLA are identified as leading the list of winners. It also notes that the five largest components—Apple, Microsoft, Amazon.com, Facebook, and Google holding company Alphabet—constitute 36% of the index's market value.

title: Apple Sued by New York Doctor Over Watch’s Heart Technology
summary: A New York University cardiologist, Dr. Joseph Wiesel, has filed a patent-infringement lawsuit against Apple Inc., claiming the Apple Watch infringes on his patented method for detecting irregular heartbeats. Dr. Wiesel is seeking compensation, asserting that Apple's Watch utilizes his invention for heartbeat monitoring. The suit was filed in federal court in Brooklyn on Friday.

title: Apple Extends Rally, Solidifying 2019 as Best Year in a Decade
summary: Apple (AAPL) shares continued their rally, hitting a new record high and cementing 2019 as the company's best annual performance in a decade, with an 82% increase for the year. This growth was boosted by strong holiday shopping sales of Apple products like AirPods and iPhones, and growing optimism for 2020 due to the anticipated 5G iPhone launch. Piper Jaffray forecasts Apple's shares to reach $305.

title: Gone in a Flash: Adobe to discontinue the plugin by end of 2020
summary: Adobe Flash, a once-ubiquitous software platform for multimedia content, is set to be discontinued at the end of 2020. This decision comes after years of vulnerability to cyber-attacks and the rise of HTML 5, which incorporates multimedia display technology, rendering Flash obsolete. Microsoft will automatically remove Flash via Windows updates, eliminating the need for users to take action.

title: Netflix was the best-performing stock of the decade, delivering a more than 4,000% return
summary: Netflix emerged as the top-performing stock of the decade, achieving an astounding return of over 4,000% for investors who bought in early. Despite perennial skepticism from analysts regarding its financial metrics and increasing competition, the company's strategic expansion into international markets and significant investment in original content have been key drivers of its success. Netflix also leverages its platform to offer creative autonomy to filmmakers, attracting top talent and high-quality productions.

title: Vanguard Information Technology ETF: Expensive, But Should Be Okay To Continue To Own
summary: The article analyzes the Vanguard Information Technology ETF (VGT), noting its portfolio of large-cap technology stocks with competitive positions. Despite its current premium valuation, the fund is deemed suitable for continued ownership due to the long-term growth outlook of its holdings and their "moaty" characteristics like recurring revenues and strong ecosystems.

title: Apple wants to bypass carriers and beam internet data directly to iPhones via satellites
summary: Apple is reportedly working on a secret project to beam internet data directly to iPhones via its own constellation of satellites, aiming to bypass traditional wireless carriers. This initiative could offer a more uniform experience for Apple users and create a new subscription-based revenue stream. The company hopes to deploy these satellites within the next five years, potentially disrupting the business models of current mobile carriers.

title: Apple has secret team working on satellites to beam data to devices
summary: Apple has a secret team of engineers working on satellite technology that could be used to beam internet services directly to devices, bypassing traditional wireless networks. The project is still in its early stages and could potentially mitigate dependence on wireless carriers or enhance location tracking for Apple devices. While the clear direction and use for satellites haven't been finalized, CEO Tim Cook's interest indicates it's a company priority.

title: Want to invest in Saudi Aramco? There’s an ETF for that.
summary: This article discusses the investment opportunity in Saudi Aramco, the world's most highly-valued company following its debut on the Saudi stock exchange. It highlights the company's valuation at roughly $2 trillion, almost double Apple Inc., and suggests that an ETF is the best way for American investors to access it despite inherent caution.

title: SAP best tech workplace in India, followed by Adobe, VMware: Report
summary: SAP has been recognized as the top-rated technology workplace in India for 2019, based on employee ratings and reviews on job site Indeed. Adobe, VMware, and Microsoft followed, with ISRO ranking fifth, moving up from tenth place in the previous year. The survey also highlighted that a significant majority of job-seekers prioritize employer reputation and online company reviews when considering new job opportunities.

title: Aeva launches ‘4D’ LiDAR on chip for autonomous driving
summary: Aeva has announced the launch of its "4D" LiDAR-on-chip system, Aeries, for autonomous vehicles, which integrates all key LiDAR elements into a miniaturized photonics chip, significantly reducing size and cost while offering advanced capabilities like instant velocity measurement. This technology is expected to cost less than $500 at scale and has received a significant investment from Porsche SE, a majority voting shareholder of the Volkswagen Group, highlighting its potential to address a major roadblock for autonomous driving adoption. The Aeries system will be officially launched at CES 2020.

title: Jabil narrows the CEO-to-worker pay ratio
summary: Jabil's CEO, Mark Mondello, maintained a flat compensation of $11.4 million in fiscal year 2019, but the CEO-to-worker pay ratio significantly narrowed to 1,605:1 from 2,238:1 in the previous year. This change occurred despite an increase in the median employee's total compensation. The article details executive compensation, financial performance, and upcoming shareholder votes on executive pay for the St. Petersburg-based manufacturing solutions company.

title: Intel buys Israeli AI start-up for $2 billion
summary: Intel has acquired Israeli artificial intelligence firm Habana Labs for approximately $2 billion. Habana Labs, which develops dedicated AI processors called Goya, will operate as an independent business unit reporting to Intel’s data platforms group. This acquisition marks one of the largest private exits in Israel and is particularly significant given Habana Labs had only raised $120 million prior to the deal.

title: Your complete guide to investing with a conscience, a $30 trillion market just getting started
summary: ESG investing, which considers environmental, social, and governance factors, grew to over $30 trillion in 2018 and is projected to reach $50 trillion in the next two decades. Once considered niche and potentially detrimental to returns, ESG strategies have proven to be market-beating and are gaining significant momentum as investors demand greater transparency and companies face consequences for not adapting. The article explores various ESG strategies, highlighting their growing popularity, market performance, and the factors driving this surge, particularly among younger generations and institutions.

title: Apple launches new “Ultimate Rivals” sports game franchise on Apple Arcade
summary: Apple has launched a new sports game franchise called "Ultimate Rivals" on Apple Arcade, developed by Bit Fry Game Studios. The first title, "Ultimate Rivals: The Rink," allows players to combine superstar athletes from multiple professional sports for two-on-two hockey matches. The franchise, which features licensed athletes from major sports leagues, aims to offer innovative gameplay and will expand with an NBA-licensed basketball game in spring 2020.

title: Apple IPO makes instant millionaires, December 12, 1980
summary: On December 12, 1980, Apple launched its IPO, selling 4.6 million shares at $22 each under the stock symbol “AAPL” on NASDAQ, generating more capital than any IPO since Ford Motor Company in 1956. The IPO instantly created about 300 millionaires, including many Apple employees, and propelled Steve Jobs' wealth to $217 million. Despite fluctuations, Apple's stock continued to grow, particularly with the introduction of consumer electronics like the iPod and iPhone.

title: Buy or Sell a Car via Mobile with the New eBay Motors App
summary: eBay Motors has launched an all-new, automotive-focused app for Apple iPhone and Android, designed to streamline the buying and selling of vehicles. The app leverages advanced technology, including AI and machine learning, to offer features like license plate scanning for automatic listing population and AI-powered image sorting, promising an elevated experience for both buyers and sellers. Users can now easily list a car in under five minutes, browse a vast inventory with personalized homepages, and utilize robust filters.

title: XP Stock Price Soars on First Day, Outperforms Saudi Aramco IPO
summary: Brazilian finance firm XP skyrocketed 24% in its multibillion-dollar IPO, outperforming Saudi Aramco's debut. XP's shares surged as much as 26% on its first day of trading, raising nearly $2 billion and valuing the company at roughly $18 billion. This strong performance comes after a year of several disappointing IPOs, including Uber and Lyft.

title: 'Fully Loaded,' Apple’s New Desktop Mac Pro Costs Over $52,000 — and Don't Forget the $400 Wheels
summary: Apple has launched its new Mac Pro desktop computer with pricing options that can exceed $52,000 for a fully loaded version, excluding the optional $400 wheels. The base model starts at $5,999, but upgrades like increased RAM to 1.5 terabytes cost an additional $25,000, significantly raising the total price. This high cost, especially when factoring in additional purchases like the Pro Display XDR and its stand, has drawn comparisons to the price of a car.
